Not that I expected a "party scene" in this hotel I thought it would a bit more lively than it actually was. After checking in, we walked around looking for a restaurant to eat at (this was at 10pm) and we couldn't even find a decent place to eat.
Like others mentioned I was annoyed at the lack of a fridge in the room. I've been to worse hotels that had pubic hairs in the sheets, lipstick\/makeup streaks on the pillow case, gross stains on the floor etc but those rooms had a fridge. I drink a lot of water and we usually stock our hotel room fridge with bottled water b\/c I drink before I sleep, in the middle of the night and first thing in the morning. And drinking room temperature bottled water doesn't necessarily sound too refreshing.
Also we had to bring our laptop so the fiance could monitor his work email periodically but for $12.99 daily rate, a wireless connection was not provided. Instead you had to attach your laptop to this short tether of a cable cord. 
We opted for this rather economic "resort" nicely located on the strip rather than stay the higher rated Wynn. I'm thinking, OK this is Vegas. We're not here to lounge all day in a nice hotel. We only need it for sleeping, showering, and to hold our stuff\/luggage. Other than that, we were going to be out.  Don't get me wrong, the hotel itself was decent but next time when I'm in town, I think I'll be booking at the Wynn.

Never again.  The rooms are not that nice and the charges are outrageous.  We checked in for a three night stay which I got at a great deal since we stayed last year (which was just bad as well, but I thought I would give them a second chance and take advantage of saving some money), but then they wanted to add an additional 50.00 (150.00!!)  per night as security ON TOP OF the 20.00 per day "resort fee"!!?!?  I don't think so!! I think they got the clue when I told them I would not be paying that and we were more than prepared to take our business elsewhere.  All of a sudden they were "nice enough" to "waive" that made up fee.  NEVER AGAiN!!! DON'T DO IT!!!!  If you don't have the money to visit Vegas properly, save a little longer! This place is a discgrace to Vegas!!

My husband and I came here for a wedding...we were not expecting much but we were quite happily surprised with what we got. The rooms are not brand new BUT they are clean..the service is nice..the food is good & the on site food court is quite fab. I also LOVED the location for shopping..Ross..marshals..planet hollywood shops!  & if you want high class just pop on over to city center which is next door..we had a fun and great stay..only gave 4 because the rooms could use a tiny upgrade here or there but other than than we had a nice stay :)

We stayed here fearing the worst due to it being a cheaper hotel and the reviews not being as stunning as some of the others. It honestly was pretty great. 

Let's put it this way. On a normal day you would stay here and think it's fantastic. However, if you have stayed in other flashier hotels in Vegas with bigger rooms, then you will think this place is crap. 

It is a little outdated, but the rooms are still large enough and the service is top notch. We came to Las Vegas last minute and didn't want to spend $300 bucks a night, so we stayed here. 

Overall, it's a nice little place and is not as horrible as some might make it seem. Still, if you can get one of the nicer hotels like the Venetian at a great price, I would stay there.

It smells here. I dont like it. It smells like 1970's carpet deodorizer. Like...carpet fresh or renuzit. Either way, it's bad.
Sadly, you get used to it after a little bit but I dont like it. Excaliber is like that too. I dont know what "air freshening" system you use, but it sucks! Call Aria and ask who they use.
3 stations for check in. 100 people in line. we are on an hour and a half wait still to check in. so disappointing. i regret.coming here.
stayed here with a few friends for a bdai ...service is quick and the pool fit a lot of people comfortably...rooms are decent tho nothing special

Stayed here 3 nites only because I had a conference to attend.  Employees are like robots; they don't give a damn of you are there or not.  Waited over 20 minutes at a BJ Table for someone to accept my MLife card and rate my play.  Poor dealer called management in pit 3 times and each time magement just looked and stayed away from the table.  Would not stay here again; Harrahs and their properties have this place beat.

Rooms are so awful. Outdated and NOTHING in them! Seriously a single desk chair, and round table- had to ask for another chair otherwise my boyfriend couldn't sit down. Asked for a fridge but they said it's an extra $25 a night. No minibar, coffee maker, not even a pen and pad of paper! Worse than a motel room. Sink and tub water don't drain quick enough so there's standing water.... 2 of the 3 days housekeeping never came, we had to call once and the second time it happened we just gave up. Only gave 2 stars because the hotel itself is in a good location. If there was a way to cancel we would have immediately.

Hotel is pretty dated the bathroom features are old, they obviously don't clean thoroughly our hallway carpet was filled with stains. Example their was a single rose petal that stayed in the same hallway location my entire 4 day stay.
Check- in took 1hr 
I had a double Room but they only placed 1 set of towles in that Room. No coffee or fridge in standard room, but yet you pay resort fees
Finally the pool is closed.

My mom, sister, and I stayed at the Monte Carlo for 4 nights, and I don't think any of us have anything bad to say about the place. The check in line was long upon arrival, but that's pretty standard at any hotel on the strip. The woman who helped me at the front desk was such a delight - super sweet, even comped the $30 early check in fee (without my asking) and got us a room higher up with a great view of the T-Mobile Arena. 

As for the room itself: don't come here if you're looking for luxury bells and whistles. Like previous reviewers mentioned, things desperately need updating. However, we weren't planning on spending much time in the room and our main priority was cleanliness. Speaking of, our room was cleaned to perfection every single day; no easy feat with 3 messy women sharing a bathroom! I was sure to leave housekeeping a nice tip for their effort!

We spent a lot of our free time by the pool, which we enjoyed. A word of caution: reserve your lounger in advance, otherwise you'll be stuck in the shade most of the day, if you even get a chair at all. It gets really busy! I feel like there are other hotels with much larger pools, but we only used the lazy river to cool off and that was enough to keep us happy.

Be SURE to check out Sambalatte downstairs - the most incredible coffee! We enjoyed a latte every single morning, and all agreed we were sad to leave solely because of this place, lol.

All in all, it was an enjoyable stay! The staff, no matter where we went, were always friendly and greeted us with a smile, and the hotel is centrally located and easy to navigate. I don't plan on coming back to Vegas any time soon (4 days is too much of Sin City, in my opinion) but if\/when I do, I'd stay at the Monte Carlo again.

Not very impressed at all. I booked a "suite" anticipating the type of suites I am used to in Vegas. I was very dissapointed with how lack lustre it was. It definitely should not be classified as such. The employee that checked us in told us that we would have a "beautiful view of the pool" which ended up being the tops of air conditioner units. I called down to express my concerns and they told me that there were no other rooms available and I was basically just screwed. there was no offer of any kind of resolution. The casino was good and the food was good but everything else was not worth it. I will never book this hotel again.

Monte Carlo is great for location, Diablos restaurant, Andres cognac lounge (upstairs) and good BJ tables. .. but.. the rooms are just basic type rooms - tub\/shower combos, plain bedspreads, etc.  for the majority of rooms. There are some spa rooms and such but for that price you can stay elsewhere.. They do a good slot tournament also if you are a slot player!

I know, everyone is probably thinking, um, the Monte Carlo?!?  Never heard of it...why would I want to stay there?  I want to stay at the Bellagio or some place swanky!

And that is when I'm going to call you a n00b.  Because let's review what one does when one come to Vegas: drink, gamble, shop, eat, and do inappropriate things that you can't get away with in your dinky little hometown.  Notice that none of those items include "sleep" or "bed" (not even doing the inappropriate things.  If you're doing it right, it'll be out in public with a cop on the verge of arresting you.  Heh.  I kid.  Sort of.).  So why blow all that money on staying in the Bellagio (BTW, the non-suite rooms are pretty tiny), when you're only go to use it to pass out?

Now that that's been covered, here's why the Monte Carlo rocks my socks:

1) It has a great location!  Centrally located across from MGM and Luxor, right on the Strip.

2) Rooms are big and roomy and very clean.  Not overly imaginative in the decor, but hey, I didn't come to Vegas to spend all my time in a hotel room (see paragraph 2 of this review)!

3) Not overly themey.  Don't get me wrong, I love all the theme hotels - I can spend hours in the Venetian or the Bellagio walking through their lobbies and shops, but I don't like to stay there, because I don't want to deal with annoying tourists (yes, I know I'm one too) while trying to get back to my room to pass out from drinking waaaaay too much.

4) The staff is generally very nice.  Each time I've come, I've asked for a room with a view of the Strip and each time, the front desk is able to accomodate me without giving me dirty looks or hem and haw over prices or any other nonsense.

5) There is a GREAT diner in this hotel, which seems like the lamest thing to be excited about...except when you've been awak for 26 hours and realized that you haven't eaten a bite for 20 of those hours, and you're on the verge of passing out but you need to get some food in you before you do, or you may die and never awaken.

6) It's connected to the Tram that will take you over to the Luxor and all that.  The Deus bus stop is right out front.  Yes, I hate walking so this really matters a lot to me.

7) The price!  Even before I start hitting up all the discount price sites for steals and deals, the rooms are usually around $60 - $100\/ night.  After I start searching for deals, I can usually snag the room for about $39\/night.  Um, HECK YEAH!  Especially considering where it's located!

The best non-sleazy hotel value on the strip.

I think people miss the point about the Monte Carlo.  Sure there's no attractions and it's kind of boring.  But, because of that, no one wants to stay there, it's rarely sold out, and they are forced to keep rates low.  It is right in the middle of the action on the strip, and the next step down in hotel is a pretty steep drop off.

The Monte Carlo is clean, modern, safe, centrally located, and has a decent array of dining options, just like its better-known siblings.  It is more of an adult hotel due to the lack of attractions for kids.  It has no interesting gimmicks like surrounding hotels but that's why you go visit them--you don't have to pay $400+\/night to the Bellagio to enjoy the grounds.  

If rates are the same, I would pick another more interesting hotel, but the Monte Carlo is usually a better value and the last hotel available before you start getting into casinos that have 60-year-old chain-smoking cocktail waitresses named Trudy waddling around providing visuals you could have done without.

The best part about this hotel was the staff they were so accommodating and friendly. Very disappointed in the rooms, ripped bedding , broken lamp shades, old tubs, caulking falling out around tub, no chairs on room, beds old . Needless too say won't be coming back till they decide to renovate.

Me and Bf want to try a new hotel from the Mlife properties and Monte Carlo was one of them.
Bf arrived and check in before i did, and was already out and about when i flew in. 

Pick up my keycard from the frontdesk was easy breezy, then head up to the room. 
Oh boy, as I was changing and getting readying I notice a moth by the phone. Then i found another one in the bathroom flying around the light. I called my bf back ASAP to rescue me lol.

He took them out of the room. Okay so i can breathe easy now. But dang, after a couple hours out, and when we came back...another moth appeared...this isnt Pokemon ppl. I don't need a wild Venomoth appear for me to catch on my mini getaway.

Dont know if they are coming from the vent? but yea it was unpleasant. 

The bed isn't that comfy either....oh well~ till next adventure Vegas!

I talked a friend of mine to stay at Monte Carlo because it was the only place we found that had a jacuzzi in the room.  Unfortunately for the price, it was not worth it.

Pros:
- Bed and couch were comfortable
- Shower was very roomy for two people
- AC works very well

Cons:
- Paid over $70+ in hotel fees ( this was my friend's complaint; I expected as much)
- Furniture is old and in bag shape. Lot of scratched and worn down pieces.
- HDMI was disabled on the TV
- Sewer smell in the shower
- Jacuzzi does not have jet capabilities so it's just a big tub and the faucets were loose.

Next time we will stay at MGM as the rooms are updated.

I'm extremely impressed with the customer service offered at the Monte Carlo. 
My boyfriend and I booked a room here for 4 nights. I'm extremely allergic to fabric softener and the 3rd day of 5 I woke up with hives that spread across my body meaning I was exposed to fabric softener. I called the the housekeepers and asked if they use it for there sheets and towels. Because they send the laundry of an off site location they didn't know. The lady I spoke with asked why so I told her of my allergy. She managed to track down NEW sheets and pillow cases for the bed, (Meaning they were never sent off site to be washed) and someone delivered them to my room. Shortly after housekeeping called and asked if I wanted someone to come make up my bed which I had already done.

Also we had amazing customer service at the car rental place in the hotel. (I can't remember the name) the guy that helped us was amazing. He knew his facts about traveling to hoover dam as well as the grand Canyon. He upgraded us from a compact to a small SUV with no charge, he was funny, friendly and polite. 

Even though this hotel is older and could use some upgrades, there people that work here are amazing.

We stayed here for March madness and spring break for 69 bucks a night!! What a deal!!
This is probably the easiest way to handle this review:
ROOM -
The first night we got stuck with two queens vs. a king. BOO.  Second night we were graciously moved to a better room.  The problem is that there are about 5 buildings going up around the hotel at the same time.  So LOTS of construction noise, even on the 26th floor.  
The bathroom was ok but no vent and shower did not drain well.  I liked that they have that shower curtain that doesn't stick to you and the toiletries that come in the room are very good quality (surprising!).  The room view was cool cause we were up so high, but the damn Lane Burton do not disturb sign would NOT stay on the door!!
The queen beds were super bad but the king was comfortable.  Overall I would stay here again.
THE POOL:
The bar is good.  You are gonna need a stiff drink to ignore the 5 buildings going up around the pool and blocking most of the sun.  I would recommend going in early afternoon to try to lay out.  Good luck.
There is a diving pool, wave pool, lazy river, huge hot tub, and then some weird unmarked and fenced off pool (for cabana use?  adults only?  who knows?)
Mostly the lack of sun was the issue here.  And the construction.  

CASINO:
This is a smaller casino but my friends won a bunch.  I signed up for their player's card and there are signs everywhere that state that for 500 points you get 25 bucks free play.
I try to cash in my 1000 points the last day and got FIVE dollars in free play.  What a rip off.  I felt gypped.
I didn't win SH*T.

There is a cool place called Diablo's attached to the casino with good food, upstairs view of strip and GREAT drinks.  Loved the Frida Khalo.  Highly recommend this place.
The monte carlo I would recommend if you don't want to spend a bunch of time in your own hotel.  But for the price, I couldn't beat it.
Oh and the food court inside - There is a McDonald's nazi!!! WATCH OUT!

Travel is dismayingly full of bait-and-switch mindphuckery, with many cities duking it out for the high distinction of possessing the largest disparity between Expectation and Reality. Monte Carlo at Vegas doesn't have a dog in that fight; it's a rather shining example of "Well, there ya go." What you see in photos is what you get. What you glean from the reviews of fellow Yelp-ers and Tripadvisors is, again, what you get: Prime location, B- ambience, amazingly comfortable beds, fitness center, large enough pool that one (namely me) can keep a safe distance from the vacant vocal-fry dialogue of drunk college girls, enough cuisinal offerings to satiate most palettes (unless you have a hankering for Maltese but only if the fenkata preparation is faithful to its historical origins, and if you are this douchebag, please go insert your head in an oven).

I can't vouch for the casino at Monte Carlo, though. I'm not a gambler on the basis that I wouldn't deposit the balance of my checking account into a wood chipper, so what makes an illuminated box with a lever any more sensible? (There was, however, an obnoxiously cute "OMG Kittens!" machine, but I abstained). Better question, what the hell does someone like me even do in Vegas? One word: Schadenfreude. Pure Schadenfreude. I recommend the Monte Carlo to travelers on a ~$200-$250\/night budget who plan to leave the premises for most\/all of the activities on their itinerary, save for sleep and a dip in the pool\/jacuzzi.

We have stayed here several times in the past, you can read my previous reviews. We were aware that the Monte Carlo is changing into "Park" a swank "new" place. We have stayed in other MGM properties, but kind of liked this one for it's proximity to the arena, position on the strip, restaurants, food court, etc. Ugh...that's all changed now! 
    The Good...we stayed in a newly renovated HP room on the 22nd floor. The rooms are much more modern than the past, there are new carpets in the halls + rooms, new paper, etc. The room was very good, clean and had ample space.
   The Bad...There are a LOT less machines and tables on the floor. It is very confusing to move around this place right now. In a few days, they will be closing 800 Degrees, the Double Barrel, the Saltimblatte cafe, and the Diablo Cantina place. The food court and small shops are totally gone. There are 2 places left to eat, a new high end steak house, and a smaller "wanna' be"  French type restaurant. Neither are really good in my opinion, and both are expensive. There is no place for breakfast, zippo, nada, nil. There is ONE set of bathrooms, so you can expect to walk about 100 yards from wherever you are on the floor...maybe more. The pool is gone, but you are welcome to use their other pools, if you don't mind walking about 3\/4 of a mile in your bathing suit, across Las Vegas Boulevard to wherever. They won't take anything off your bill for this, I mean...Hey...it's Vegas you know!
   The Ugly...construction and workers are ongoing everywhere here. It's extremely noisy outside, the dust outside will cover your car in a day. There's dust inside too, just look at the small lights over the elevators to see what you will be breathing. Entering from the garage, at the top of the escalator, it smells like a toilet. Like methane or people peeing on the walls, I don't know what the smell is, it's gross! In the lobby there's a giant tree trunk, root piece of crap on the ceiling. No clue how that is upscale! Inside the elevators the carpet is still old. The elevators are still 50 or 60 years old and slow. Where the shops and food court was, it's...construction, like it was LAST YEAR. We grow tired of it and probably are not going to return here again.
   One interesting note for slot players. We played about 1K a day, I was kind of racking up points and my GF wasn't. Naturally, we didn't win any money, but...Hey...it's Vegas, we planned to spend and lose, that was the plan, really. Anyways, my GF likes to play the big flashy, progressive machines like the Wonka deal. I noticed those machines had a tiny plaque saying they were "specialty" games. The next day we went to the rewards window and asked about that. It seems regular games earn 1 point for about 3 dollars in. The "specialty" games win 1 point for $10.00 in. We never heard of that, I've been gambling for about 25 years.
   The truth is, we live an hour from Mohegan + Foxwoods, and go there a lot. There are like 20 restaurants in each, countless shops + machines. Want dessert? No problem. Want to dine? No problem. Want to eat cheap? No problem. Want Asian, Italian, Mexican, American, breakfast, or whatever food? No problem. This place and Vegas are not really as appealing as they used to be !!!

This is the 3rd time I've been to Vegas!!! The worst experience I've ever had, I checked in in the afternoon, when we get in the room sink was plugged! We supposed to get one king size bed they gave us 2 queen beds...... I can hear my neighbor talk about where they gonna go, and not surprised they throw a party at 2 am, it's Vegas I know!!! But come on~~~ go out and party please! 

Most importantly don't let the beautiful pix on their website fool you, from the experience if " The Ventian" and Bellagio , this place looks like a 90 dollars roadway inn!!!

Don't come, if you wanna have fun in Vegas

Just a review for the pool area...

We scored a daybed on a Thursday, because we thought the deal was a steal. $200 for a private area, and you can spend that $200 on food and drink? Perfect. 

We show up at 9:00, and the $200 daybeds were situated in the shade. We asked the attendant when we could expect some sun, and she told us "not until 2:00 or 3:00"

Hang on a second. I am from the midwest. I haven't seen sun in 7 months. I want some sunshine. She told us that we could upgrade for another $125...so we did. We wound up in the red daybeds situated by the lazy river, which was pretty perfect. The private area is choice. 

We started off with pina coladas and muffins for breakfast, and everything was off to an awesome start. The sun appeared over the hotel at about 10:00, and we basked our pale asses off. 

Then things kind of went downhill. We had $325 to spend on food and drink, which seemed manageable...but the food is AWFUL. Everything is heavy, greasy, and not what you want to eat poolside. The chicken fajita nachos and artichoke and spinach dip were our first tries, and we barely touched them. The other lunch options sounded even heavier, so we opted out. Sitting in 90 temperatures, I do not want a giant beef sandwich, or a large greasy burger. Blech. The folks in the daybed next to us said their flatbread pizzas were pretty soggy and gross.

The fruit plate was decent. So...order thirty of those?

When all was said and done, we wound up ordering a bunch of beer to bring back to the hotel, which is cool that they let you do. The bill with all of the service and included gratuity was $422. It was a nice experience, but not a $422 experience. So minus one star for the crappy food and price, and minus another star for not including the fact that the $200 daybeds will be in the shade almost all day on the website.

I'm also giving the Monte Carlo  3 stars. The hotel is a bit dated, No amenities in the room like a coffee maker or mini fridge.  Mattress was just ok, my back didn't hurt but I was happy to get out of bed in the morning.  Our shower was a little funky, it leaked from the faucet and it was hard to get the heat adjusted. Like many big casino hotels, our room was pretty far from the elevator and it was on the 31st floor so it takes a while to get anywhere. I felt like I was out on the south forty. 
Despite all this I would stay again, the price was right and the kids liked the pool area. The tram to the Bellagio is nice and very convenient.
Other Pros: The self parking and the location on the strip.

I've watched all those shows on the Travel Channel. "Vegas AFTER DARK!" "Vegas: A VIP Tour!" "Vegas Gives You a Handjob and then Bakes You Cookies (But Only After Vegas Washes Its Hands First.)"  It all looks so glamorous, so sparkly. Neon dreams washing over doe-eyed faces; the visuals alone are worth the price of admission. 

What no one ever mentions, though, are....the smells. Perfume, cigarettes, urine, Axe Body Spray, cigarettes...um, what is that? Chinese food? Oh, and the cigarettes. Each hotel and casino has its own scent, depending on its age and clientele. Binions, downtown, smelled of menthols and Ben Gay. Traces of suntan lotion, Axe Body Spray and Pall Malls wafted through the Excalibur while the Imperial Palace reeked of Virginia Slims and despair.

This brings me to the Monte Carlo. The Monte Carlo is a middle-range hotel, by Strip standards. While not as dismal as that time I stayed at The IP (Room 13, natch), it's not as high-end as Aria or the Bellagio or wherever George Clooney goes to get his penis washed. However, Monte Carlo's location is nice. It's centrally located (relatively speaking) and the free tram to Aria and the Bellagio is a big help for weary footsies.

And the smell?  It was somewhere between Windex and Marlboro Reds. Actually, no. It leaned more towards the Marlboro Reds, especially in my room. Yeah, we requested a non-smoking room, but it still smelled like 1967 in there. We should've immediately requested another room, but after quickly dropping off our bags and then going full tilt that first day, it wasn't until the Day One Vegas buzz wore off that we noticed that we had just bunked up Joe Camel's asshole. The smoke permeated everything, from the sheets to the towels.

We lived with it. The wife scored a candle from a friend and that helped. 

Other than that, the room was ok. It was nothing special, but nothing horrible either. The wave pool was empty, which disappointed us a bit. The "lazy river" looked uninspired from our perch waiting for the Bellagio tram, though admittedly, we didn't look closer than that. The check-in clerk was adorably perky and helpful. The price wasn't bad either. Oh and I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the showerhead. That thing was like being pressure washed every morning which, for most people vacationing in Las Vegas, is probably necessary. It sounds like I'm complaining about the showerhead, but I'm not. The showerhead was easily one of my top three favorite things about Las Vegas and that includes my outrageously expensive meal at Jose Andres' e'. In all, I would've given the Monte Carlo 4 stars were it but for the smoke.

Damn you, you smokers. This is why we can't have nice things.

The pool scene is awesome for partying. I went here back in late April and had a great time, but the price was pretty high. The pool was the saving grace here...it is more in the middle of the strip, but it does take a while to get to another casino (unlike the walkways to luxor, Excalibur, NYNY, and MGM). We had fun and the pool scene was great...the lazy river was awesome, but definitely don't get too drunk and go in. Tipsy in it I had a great time, but I saw drunkerds lose it and pass out...the push current can be too  much if you've had too much. The pool was the only exciting part of the place.

Classy, Classic, Charming!  One of the last hotel\/casinos with that "old Vegas" feeling and appeal while remaining modern and up-to-date.  Staff members, from house-keeping to parking valet (John is the best!)  to upper management, are all extremely friendly, helpful and knowledgeable.  The pool area is gorgeous, relaxing and has lots of shade available if you're not one to sit in the sun all day.  Lazy River is a perfect way to end your day relaxing and enjoying a cocktail before heading out for the night.  The Pub inside the hotel is a great place for a casual dinner with upscale feel.  And, let me tell you about the  Cupcake bakery!  My special-needs niece turned 21 and wanted to experience Vegas.  I went to the cupcake bakery and ordered 21 cupcakes to be delivered to us after dinner (at The Pub).  When they were delivered, I just about fell over!  They arranged the cupcakes in the number 21, placed candles on each one AND, included 4 exra cupcakes at no charge in a small 'to go' box for her to take back to her room.  And, they were so sweet to her, they stuck around to sing Happy Birthday!

And now, we must say goodbye to our old friend.  With it's closing goes customer-service at it's very best, that VIP\/High-roller feeling without the wallet to back it up, smiling faces on the staff that were truly happy to see you and serve you.  Those beautiful chandeliers in the lobby, pool-side party atmosphere and yes, free valet parking!!  (I'm still having a problem with this, Corporate greed wants you to pay to park your car to spend money in their hotel).  Next will be having to pay for drinks at the tables!  

Good bye to the loyal staff that gave so many years of experience and first class customer-service to all those who walked through their doors.

Good by old friend.  Thank you for the memories I keep with me.  Thank you for the friendships forged pool-side, at the bar(s) and restaurants.  Thank you for making our hearts beat a little faster with anticipation of arriving at your door.  THANK YOU!

Honestly, this is in all likelihood the dumpiest hotel on the strip. It really should be demolished like they did with the Sands. Got sucked through a "Name your price" bid with Priceline when I bid for a 4 stars hotel... this is so far away from a 4 stars that it's laughable. Priceline is complicit with this rating and should not be trusted either. Come here or use Priceline at your own risk. You have been warned.

I will never stay at this hotel again, from day one everything turn out wrong but i wanted to give them a chance. Besides that the bathroom tub was clogged every time we shower everything seem good. The last day was when i couldn't believe it when i got a call from my bank while i was out. They asked me if i was trying to purchase at Wal-Mart for 250.00,  i was so confused for a sec but then i remember i had left my wallet in my room. The first thing i thought was they had probably taken my credit card and used it. I immediately went back to my room and thats when i found that not just my card was missing but my wallet was missing. Thats not all but everyone's wallets were gone!!! I called monte carlo security and management and all they did is had us telling them what has happened and wrote a report. We stayed up all night calling the banks and trying to find out who had done it. My friends and i were doing all the work and when morning came the hotel told us that it was not their responsibility even tho it got stolen inside the room. The excuse they gave us is that their cameras weren't the best ones and they didnt know who did it so they didnt know what to tell me. The person that did it knew were we kept our wallets cause they didnt make any mess. Im pretty sure it was a inside employee and the knew it. This has been the worst experience ever.

Went to visit a buddy that was staying at the Monte Carlo.  I recommend coming in off of Frank Sinatra.  I was able to negotiate traffic with ease.  Parking was tight but the garages are long so I was able to find a spot on the second floor.

Coming across the catwalk and into the casino, I instantly became lost and roamed around for awhile before finding the elevators. My bad at times I am to stubborn to read.

While on my walk I did look things over.  Even thought the Monte Carlo has been around awhile it still had a certain pop to it.

I thought it strange that there was not a security guard doing key checks at the elevators but I hopped right on.

Once I made it to the floor I saw just how long the hallways were.  I mean they seem really long in this place.  Depending on where your room is at it's a long walk to get ice.

The rooms were clean and felt comfortable.  It was a double bed but the room only had one chair.  I guess my only complaint was that they did not have NFL Network that could be played on the old school television set.

I would recommend if the price was right to an out of towner but would look elsewhere for a staycation.

These are the hotels that piss me off.  It's an average hotel in good hotel clothing!  This goes for places like New York New York too!....Just cuz they throw in a magic show and some nice carpet doesn't make this place a resort.  
Oh...and I'm officially banned from this hotel.  Damn my college roommates.

On arrival we were stung with 20 dollar\/day "resort fee", per day plus tax.

Bed's were comfy, but walls thin, loads of teenagers partying.  We just stayed on the third floor, so not great views.  It was better value than other hotels in the area.

We had a great time at this hotel.  The staff was friendly, the rooms were nice and the pool area was great.  
Get to the pool early, because seats fill up FAST!
My only real complaint comes wit h the tubes for the lazy river.  We're already paying a resort fee, do we really deserve to be charged another 10 bucks for an inner tube?!

The Monte Carlo - which pretends that it is a businessman\/businesswoman's hotel in addition to a casino - has gone downhill.

Technology in the room is state-of-the art 1996.   No wifi. No HD.  An alarm clock from 1976.
Food and beverage options: watered down drinks.  Nothing that approaches fresh fruit and vegetables among restaurant choices.

Need I go on?

Exercise gear that is broken for days.
A checkin\/checkout system that verges on chaos.  And a "enforcer" in the lobby that berates guests on checkin.
Finally: a management that is clueless and tone deaf when a business customer calls to register complaints.

And yes- the rooms smell of "old"    If you are in town for business and expect your hotel to provide contemporary guest services, look elsewhere.

First off, upon checking in- they didn't have the room that we paid for... Therefore have placed us in another room and promised to call us from 1-5 for a room change the next day, that never happened.... I was going to let it go but as I Returned to room at 6 pm... My Room is still messy... Spoke with front desk, staff said they start cleaning at around 11 am. No promises on clean room upon return.. What the f***?! What's good of a hotel if you can't return to clean room? So I mentioned that they never contact me for a room change for the whole day.. No apology from staffs member.. Not very good customer service. She did change my room ... But to a smaller room (can hear neighbors' convo- like every single word) talk about asshole move... Had to go down and request another room change. New room was perfect, big and less noise. The second day of stay is very good!!! Seems like everything was done perfectly.... I'll give this place a four mainly cuz of the bad experience on day 1... However, it's walking distance from pretty any place on the strip. You can take the tran from here to aria and from aria to ballagio and back, saved a lot of walking time

This hotel will be great once the renovations are completed, currently they are on the 19th level.  Arrive early to secure a room away from construction otherwise your mornings will be spent sleepless and restless with the noise of jackhammering. 

The hotel layout is as to be expected for the casino.  We arrived around 18.00 (6pm) and our rooms were not ready and we had to wait. The line for check in were very long. 

The room was adequate, beds were average. Most areas behind the furniture had never been cleaned.  The major issue we had was the level of noise from the hotel renovations and from the construction outside.  This should have been made clear during check in and some form of credit or voucher issued. 

Of note after explaining my issue during checkout. Jozy (manager on duty) was very helpful. 

From a security perspective the hotel is reasonably secure. There are guards that do roving patrols on the casino and also on the different floors ( I never saw these guard). The biggest flaw is that the elevators are not manned by any guards, unlike other hotels, which offers the additional security.
Rooms are big and hotel is pretty clean but the only problems is it is VERY LOUD.  The walls are peper-thin!  If you don't sleep in like I love too, then you shouldnt have a problem.

I booked 3 nights at this hotel through bookit.com which was very easy but did not include the fact that the low rates you get are not really that low. There is a resort fee of $30 a night which you find out about at check-in making the rates not really low at all.  Then there is the charge for parking.  All M-Life hotels are now charging for parking.  No other hotels do that except MGM and Monte Carlo and the other M-Life hotels.  The room was supposed to be a deluxe strip view. You can see the strip but the actual view is of the roof of the building and the air conditioners with the strip in the distance.  So, overall, the hotel was disappointing and I will not patronize anymore because they make enough money there to take care of the parking at least.

We came here at 0730 hours on a Saturday morning just because we could. I mean, the corollary to going to bed by 2200 hours on a Friday night WHILE IN VEGAS has to be gambling way early on Saturday, right? Anyway, my bf turned his $100 into $182 (there we go high rolling again) and I had some fun playing slots. The food court seemed pretty awesome, but my bf was disappointed when Nathan's was only serving breakfast and not hot dogs...think about it. Wouldn't you be? We collected his cash and went on our way.

Construction was outside out window AND in the room above us (or 2 rooms over and above, hard to tell).....jackhammers woke us at 5:30 AM...loudest construction I've ever heard at a hotel.  Even when we were awake it was so loud we could barely hear each other talk.  I had taken a Lunesta sleeping pill and had earplugs in and the noise woke me up and was so loud it was unbelievable.  Ruined the entire day being on 3 hours sleep...my wife and I could hardly function the entire next day.  Worse night's sleep in a hotel ever.  They moved us to another room, but the previous day was totally shot to hell.  We also had to cut plans short the next day to come back to the hotel to switch rooms because that was the only way we could fit it in our schedule.  I understand hotels need to have construction, but there is reasonable noise (put earplugs in and fall back asleep) and noise that wakes the dead.

Place is falling apart!  Just outside of the Blue Man Group theater is a bikini clad dancer on to of the bar ( and not good ones). Is this a down town club?  Come on Monte Carlo, clean it up, decorate, replace
torn furniture. Your on the strip and supposed to be better.

Before I got to hotel I spoke with reservations and was told I would receive the buffet with package. I got to hotel and there you have it. No buffet. And when I spoke to Stephanie at front desk she stayed there was nothing she could do about that. I also requested a king size bed and received two queen size beds and it's just me... Again I asked Stephanie at front desk can I switch my rooms out and she said no. So I'm literally over this place already.. I mean where is the customer satisfaction. This is ridiculous and it's my birthday weekend. What a waste

Stayed here for five nights and this was a pretty decent place.

Let me first start off with the pros: very clean hotel, we had a pool view on the 20th floor, bathroom was huge in the room, room was clean, staff was very polite and helpful, casino was great, and they had amazing pools. They had a lazy river, a wave pool, a regular decent sized pool, a jacuzzi, and a little v.i.p pool with a little fence surrounding it with a private cabana inside. They had cabanas all through out the pool areas, but you had to reserve them. Had a couple of bars out by the pool, and had good music playing as well. 

Cons: the rooms didn't have any refrigerator, microwave, or coffee machines. The bathroom didn't have a fan in there, so I had to shower with the door opened.. The drain was very clogged and the shower head water kept going out if I put it on a comfy setting. In the middle of the casino, there was a very foul odor almost like a sewage problem.. (it happens) at the pool, you can't bring alcohol inside the gates, so be aware! They have bars inside the gates, but, it's very pricey! In the casino, $4 for a bottle of water! As well as the little gift shop by the lobby area... Go through the casino, it leads you out to the strip, and go to the CVS next door to the hotel or go to Walgreens across the street! It's much cheaper! Also, at the casino, if you want your free alcoholic beverages, go a little earlier during the afternoon\/evening, or else you won't find barely to any servers after 7-7:30. So, you'll have to end up going to the CVS or Walgreens to buy alcohol. Unless you're there for the views and everything and not to drink! 

As you can tell, this was my very first Vegas experience, and it was amazing! I would definitely stay at the Monte Carlo again and I would definitely recommend this place! Thank you for the great experience, Monte Carlo!

I don't know why all the bad reviews. I was just here for 2 nights on the 31st floor it was quiet no construction noises and no bed bugs lol Room was clean shower was clean. The pool is closed for construction but they offer complimentary transportation over to Mandalay Bay. Busses run every 30 minutes. You can also use the MGM pool but theres no transportation to there. We will stay here again once construction is finished and check out the pool.

We have been visiting Vegas for years and had never stayed here until this last time. .Check in was easy. Our room was not ready *we arrived early* so that was no problem. Once we got our room...I was pleasantly surprised. We had a spa suite on floor #26 and it was very nice. Loved the big spa type bath tub and the water jets. We gambled a bit..didn't win but had a blast anyway. I will most definitely stay here again.

We had a delightful experience at this hotel last year.  I don't know why I didn't write a review back then.  

We initially booked this hotel because the price was decent and we were traveling with children, and the pool area looked suitable for the kiddos.  I really thought the kids and my senior-aged parents would enjoy the lazy river.  The kiddos ended up loving the wave pool as well.  The pool staff were great as well, very nice and helpful.  The pool was very easy to get to right around the corner from the elevators.  

Check in was easy-breezy.  No problems, and fairly quick.  We arrived there later in the evening and it was easy.  We also rented a scooter for my mother and the staff was so helpful in the pick up and drop off of the scooter.  Very nice and helpful as well.  

Getting to the elevators from the lobby was not too bad... You have to walk a little ways through the casino. The rooms were pretty good.  I wouldn't say they were the greatest rooms we've ever stayed in, but they had what we needed and they were clean.  

The Windows did allow quite a bit of sound into the room though.  There was a construction site next door, and we could hear the fairly constant beeping of the trucks.  I imagine once that was completed the rooms are probably pretty quiet now.  

The food court near the elevators gave our family plenty of options for meals in which everyone seemed to be pretty happy with the choices and selections.  My mom doesn't like to spend a lot of money on food when she travels, and she was fairly content.  

We enjoyed our stay and plan to stay again this spring.  I'll update with more info.
Cheap and has all the essentials. Food, casino, decent rooms, somewhere to sleep.

Great pool. Good prices. Comfortable rooms.

I'll tell you why this place is dead on the weekends -- there's no nightlife here. No big club or trendy restaurant. It's just a stopping point before starting your night. 

There are also quite a few kids here. Personally, I would never bring my kids (if I had any) to Vegas. That was such a 90s thing to do. Now, even Excalibur has "The Thunder from Down Under" which, I would like to point out, is definitely not kid friendly. 

So the kids monopolize the wave pool and the lazy river, but you don't really notice in your hungover state anyway. No matter what, this hotel is in a perfect location - easy access to all the other hotels\/casinos -- and it's always got fairly good rates.

(Review of Casino Floor and Not Hotel)

Worst casino floor experience ever. The dealers are amateurs who pay out money to the wrong people, even after you catch them they still argue their right. Apparently they forget that the eye in the sky is always watching. Supervisors\/Management are rude and do not care. Essentially no one from the management down wants your business, which is fine. With all the casino options in Vegas it is not hard to find another place to throw my money down the drain at. I would NEVER step foot on the casino floor of the Monte Carlo again ever.

Location, Location, Location! It's right next to city center and close to Planet Hollywood, MGM, etc.

I was very surprised by Monte Carlo. I was expecting a budget style hotel (for Vegas anyways) and we got anything but that. The rooms were better than I had expected and have flat screen TVs and a nice ipod hook up for music. The pool was great, we loved the lazy river and the big hot tub. If you're going to be sleeping late keep in mind that the walls are fairly thin and there's also a huge pool party blasting music we could hear from the 22nd floor. I like the casino here too, it's not too crowded and I had fun at the craps table, great dealers for the most part. I would stay at this hotel again in a second!

Hotel 32 a boutique hotel on 32nd floor is so kouch hetter then the rest of the resort..but the resort in general is fine. The service is spectactular, The restaurants offer an exceptional assortment to choose from, the dealers are nice, and the lounges were a blast. 

Conveniently located adjacent to City center as well

A bit older hotel, but the staff and casino dealers and pit bosses could not be nicer.  They experience makes losing at least a good time. : )

They need wifi in the rooms.

Gorgeous, perfectly priced for location hotel. You step out the front door and you're on the strip, stay inside and it's not too hustle bustle like some of the other hotel casinos. 

Our reservation requested a smoke-free room, and they were all booked up for the room we had reserved so they upgraded us to the 30th floor with no hesitation. When we finally went to bed after a very late night, we realized we were without toothbrushes- they quickly sent up complimentary dental kits and if your'e a sucker like I am for travel sized items- then you'd love this little set. 

We spent the next morning at the super packed pool. They offer a few different pools (lazy river, hot tub, regular pool and a wave pool) and an abundance of chairs to lay out on (grab two towels! those chairs get hot in that 109* sun). There are servers who will run around taking drink orders, but I found it faster to simply go to the pool bar. I didn't take advantage of their souvenir glass- but it's 17$, triple the alcohol and only $11 to refill, vs. the 10$ for the small glass. The frozen drinks were super sweet, a little too sweet for me. 

I would definitely come back here to stay again.

This rating is simply for the Jabbawockeez performance we watched and nothing else. I loved watching them, and I'll come back again. I can't give out to many details about the show, but I can tell you, if you like dancing, comedy, music, or you're just a big fan of the Jabbawockeez, you will definitely enjoy this show. I recommend everyone of all ages to check this show out. I found myself entertained throughout the whole show, you guys are true professionals.

Jabbowockeez you rock! Keep up the good work I'll be back for more action soon.

PS: Thanks to Duane (JBWKZ uniform manager) for hooking up our 3 boys with some autographed masks! Mad ups to the whole JBWKZ crew\/team for taking the time to keep all your fans happy. Thanks!

I actually had to drop this place one star, because my initial review was actually ONLY for the Jabbawockeez, but then I found the real yelp for the Jabbawockeez show so I decided to just put my review there instead and just rate my review here of what I actually think of the Monte Carlo with the average of the fact that the Jabbawockeez perform their. All in all this place deserves a 4 star.

I have stayed at the Monte Carlo in the past and found it nice and conveniently located, which is why, when they were having a special, I booked a weekend there again. However, as we unpacked our bags, we found that the previous guest left several shirts in the drawers. This sullied the whole stay for me because it led me to question whether their housekeeping staff was really doing a good job. They moved us to a comparable room, but I wasn't really satisfied after that. In addition, the hotel pretty much shuts down after 10pm in contrast to other hotels that are bustling into the wee hours.  If I had to stay here again, I would because it wasn't awful, but I will always look for another option after this trip.

One saving grace: free "tram" (really a monorail) to the Bellagio. This saved us a lot on transportation costs.

Stayed in this hotel my first time in Vegas, back in 2005... I thought it was like staying at the Bellagio back then (rookie)

I've been going to Vegas every other year. This year it was the "Reunion, the comeback" to The Monte Carlo.

Tsk Tsk Tsk.. no impressed. I'll start off with the Pros:
1-The location! muy bueno. you can walk to any popular spot or nightclub from this hotel 
2-The Tram: ok if you don't wanna walk (see#1), then you can take the tram that can take you from the Monte Carlo to the Aria Hotel to the Bellagio
3- the Pool: 3 different pools, one with waves!..... really mellow (except Saturday, it was poppin'!), really hot servers, and it  also has a volleyball court (not, that ur going to vegas for a pick up game of Volleyball, but just so u know)
4- ask for comp late checkout..you just might hit the jackpot and get it for frrrrreeeee!
5- not bad for the $$ BUT........

Once you enter the "deluxe" rooms with strip view:
(Cons):
1- the carpet in the room look outdated, old, somewhat dirty.
2- The "Deluxe" part of the deal for our room... i wasn't feelin' it. It felt like we were staying in a Motel 6. It had no fridge, not microwave, small bathroom
3- can't BYOD to the pool area
4- food court staff are rude, terrible, incompetent: (Starbucks: couldn't get the most basic, simple, easiest drink to prepare, right: a Chocolate milk. really!? Banana bread: bad.
Sbarros (sp): gave an incomplete order and when i made brought it up to them they were making a big deal as if I was trying to get a free meal... 
McDonald's:.... just don't go there.


The score is tied at 1 for now, 1 good experience (2005), one not so good (2013),  we'll see next time....

Solidly a 4-star hotel on the Vegas Strip. I stayed here for two nights in a room with two queen beds with 3 other friends and had a great time in LV.

The door to the bathroom stuck and the pressure on the shower head was ridiculously strong--we were on the 20th floor and there's a drought in the West!

The pool area is pretty nice. You should get down there around 10-11am before all the lounge chairs in the sun are filled up.

3.5 stars.

This review is just for the rooms and the pool. We partied, ate, and did things elsewhere.

Monte Carlo was an okay Hotel to stay in. It is priced pretty decent, but the rooms are also just decent. We had 8 people sharing two rooms (with four beds total) and we got the two rooms with a connecting door. That makes communication very easy. But there is nothing fancy or special about the rooms. But you're in Vegas, so you're here to party (and\/or gamble). So the hotel\/room choice is not that big of a deal. 

We went there last late October, and around Monte Carlo, there were constructions going on. I don't remember (hahaha) the noise to be a problem. But I did find their vehicle loading\/unloading to be positioned in a wrong place. It's not at the front, but rather it's on the side where you have to go into their alleyway. 

Their pool area is nice and big, and they have plenty of seats. But the damn unfinished\/constructing building right there wasn't that appealing. (But that is probably not the fault of Monte Carlo.)

Next time, I would try somewhere else, so to see the other selections.
One of the nicer hotels to stay at on the strip.  It's moderately priced and clean.  I never had an issue there.  The buffet is good and decently priced.

There was no complimentary water bottle in the room. There was even no coffee maker neither!!! We had to call front desk for toothbrush and toothpaste!!! Can't imagine that we had to buy a big pack of water during the stay in Las Vegas!

Stayed there Dec.14-20 in the Monaco Suite..We had no issues with the room,it was clean,neat,and a very comfy bed!  From the check in with Jessica and the check out with Eric the staff was great and were very nice and helpful...The only issue and its minor is the towels they have, could use some Downey or some sort of fabric softner...We were 18 floors up,had no issues with construction noise...The Pub was good..Loved Sambalatte..Buffet was ok,not bad..Casino is nice,and not too overwhelming and not to smokey!..Loved the Minus 5 bar,great staff had a blast for my birthday....plus you can't beat the location of the hotel and once they get it all fixed up this will be even better place to stay....We will be back!!

I was transferred to your hotel by Mlife rewards, because I was hoping to book a room with either your hotel or one of the other Mlife hotels. The man I spoke to from VIP promotions on 4\/6\/17 was so beyond rude to me on the phone when I asked a question about the resort fees, that I immediately changed my mind and booked with a bally total rewards casino...where my room was comped at no cost. I am meeting friends that week. Guess where I'm telling them to CHANGE their reservations from?

3.5 stars.

It's reasonably priced, right in the middle of the strip and they have good pools.

But the food there sucks and there is major construction going on next door which is a total headache.  

It is rather unfulfilling to observe construction while tanning by the pool. 

Still, I'd go back.

Seit 1996 gibt es am Las Vegas Boulevard das Hotel Monte Carlo, das das Frstentum Monaco gestalterisch interpretiert. Es liegt unmittelbar neben dem New York New York Hotel, das ebenfalls zur MGM Resorts International gehrt und dem City Center.

Mit 3002 Zimmern gehrt es nicht zu den greren Hotels in Las Vegas, bietet aber auch viel Luxus fr seine Gste. So gibt es 3 Pools mit Kinderbecken, Wasserflle, Wellenbad und knstlichem 120 Meter langen Flu, dem Lazy River.

Das Casino hat beachtliche 8.400 m, wo man bei Blackjack, Roulette, Craps, Pai Gow Poker, Keno, Caribbean Stud Poker, Baccarat, Renn- und Sportwetten, 2.200 Slots und Videopokergerte sein Glck herausfordern kann. Fr die reichere Kundschaft gibt es einen Players Club, den sogenannten "M life Players Club".

Sehr bersichtlich ist das eigene Shopping Center mit 20 Stores ausgefallen. Neben einem Foodcourt gibt es noch 2 Gourmetrestaurants, das Blackstone Steak House und Andre's French Restaurant. Fr Entertainment ist im Hotel auch reichlich gesorgt, unter anderem tritt im Hotel die Blue Man Group auf.

Von auen ist das Hotel liebevoll gestaltet, im Inneren habe ich keine herausragenden Stilelemente mit dem Thema Monte Carlo vorgefunden. Durch seine zentrale Lage am Strip sicherlich eine attraktive bernachtungsmglichkeit.

Nothing special about this hotel. The rooms are standard. This is 2-stars as compared to other strip hotels. It's most certainly better than normal hotels in all respects.
Gentlemen, there is no security at the elevator shafts.

Love staying at the Monte Carlo because it's affordable and there's a food court...yea the Venetian has a food court too but unless I find an amazing deal, it's way out of my price range. Checked in on a Sunday and was told its their busiest day but the lady who helped me out was very nice and cheery, like she actually likes her job! The rooms are adequate, nothing spectacular. 
But I love the lazy river at the pool and I always seem to find chairs even if it seems crowded. However, you do get what you pay for, the crowd is definitely younger. Lots of 21st birthdays being celebrated.
Love the tram that goes to Aria and Bellagio tho, cuts down a bit of the walking!

I would not stay here again.

We arrived at 3 (which is check-in) and were informed that our room was not ready.  Joy.  The check-in guy said it could be a couple hours and that someone would call us when our room was ready.  I asked for some comp drinks and was quickly denied.  When we stayed at the MGM last year, we had the same problem and the clerk offered us $50 credit without us even having to ask.  
Great, been in a plane for 3 hours, no room, what's a guy to do?  Go check out "The Pub" with over 200 beers.  We arrived at the pub about 4 which was shift change apparently.  We sat by the pool (which closes at 5 during the off months, I guess us out of towners get screwed)  Some guy who worked there cam up to us and said that it was shift change and our server would be right with us....   10 minutes later....  same story from the same guy.  10 minutes more... another table is seated next to us.  10 more minutes the server shows up and promptly helps that table... Took 10 minutes of laughing and joking before we got service.  All this time, no water, nothing.   Service was slow and terrible.  The place was not even busy.  Did not go back and would not.  
We sat there for 2 hours without a call from the front desk.  I called and they said the room was still not ready.  WTF?  We have rezzies at 7!  So, I go to the front desk and was greeted by a rude woman.  She tells me the room is now ready no apology or anything.  We finally get to the room to find nasty towels in the shower.  
The bar staff at diablos are pretty snooty as well, you can only sit at a table if you are eating, drinks and apps have to sit in the bar.  Suffice it to say, I was not impressed.  There is too much competition in Vegas to be treated this way.  I will not be back to the Monte Carlo.

Came here with my boyfriend for my birthday and stayed in the Monaco suite. Very nice! I knocked off a star because there was no blow dryer in the bathroom. I usually don't bring my own blow dryer because there's no need to carry extra weight when they're already supposed to be in the room. I found that very odd for a hotel suite to not have one. Other than that, super fun place! We were out at the pool all day yesterday drinking, dancing and ignoring the lifeguards blowing their whistles at us every 5 seconds. Chill out, guys! :)

Might as well stay in a motel because I have stayed in much nicer motel rooms. The cleaners left their rags in the room, took the soap and didn't replace it and there were stains on the chair. I might as well have used course sand paper instead of their towels as sand paper would have been softer on my skin, but that's on top of the fact I had to call twice to get the hot water fixed so I wasn't having cold showers. Also it took several seperate conversations with staff to fix the over charging to my card. On check out letting the front desk know of my issues I was told I should have spoken with someone and they would have offered me another room. I did speak with many members of staff and this was never offered. I'm just glad I couldn't hear the construction I had the "lovely view of" during my stay. For the price point there are far nicer hotels you can stay in.

We checked in on a Friday. We were assigned a room and as soon as I enter noticed that it looked like it had not been cleaned. I felt like I was at a motel 6 but paying 4 star prices!! WTF!! We asked to be changed to another room which they promptly did. The 2nd room was much nicer. BUT why at 30 floors up am I woken up by the music at the pool????

This hotel try to be something it isn't. It was great back when it opened but now its past it prime and their prices should reflect that. It reminded me why I always will pay a little bit more to stay at the Wynn\/Encore.

Weekend buffet: grossly expensive, yet possibly the worst in town. Any average clueless bachelor can cook half-decent salmon--but not these clowns. Hard and dry through and through, like pieces of compressed pink fiber insulation. They actually made a clunking sound when dropped on a plate. Unbelievable and laughable. This place isn't even trying.

This just happened today and I will never stay here again! We asked for our room to be cleaned at 6:30 PM, that way while we attended the Blue Man show our room could be cleaned while we were out for a few hours. When we returned 6 HOURS later after midnight our room was still dirty! We called the front desk and sent housekeeping like 15 minutes later, which was a huge inconvenience because we had to stay awake while she cleaned the room. Mind you our plane was scheduled to depart at 6 AM, we were exhausted, and we had to be awake by 4 AM to catch our flight out. 

The night before they turned the water off without notice from 11 PM to 5 AM, so when we came back we weren't able to take a shower, brush our teeth or anything for hours. Housekeeping brought us a 3 bottles of water, but that's no good when you want to wash up from a hectic day out. We had the spa suite, but they had no microwave in the room and no access to one anywhere, so there was no way to heat up our food, which would have been convenient for us. 

They did comp us by removing the resort fee, and $54 buffet bill, but the overall experience was just horrible and disappointing, especially when you're hyped up to stay somewhere you think is going to be nice.

We have stayed at Monte Carlo for years, 3 to 5 times a year. This time ruined it for us. When we booked no one told us about the construction. We went to enjoy the pool one last time for the summer. It was closed and all the shopping areas. We spoke to a so called manager Jamie Schmidt. The worse manager I have ever seen . we checked into our room and the toilet did not work . we called maintainance they came and worked on it and flooded our bathroom ,using our towels to clean it. He called  housekeeping to come clean up the mess they took forever to get there. In the process we missed dinner plans with friends. I contacted Jamie Schmidt whose only reply was maybe you should have asked for another room. We are platinum card holders on Mlife I threw the damn card away as I don't want a thing to do with MGM in anyway. Time to find a new favorite. Stay away from Monte Carlo  they don't care about customers

My husband and I stayed here about 10 years ago and really enjoyed it and my parents stayed here a couple years ago and said the same. Unfortunately that was not the case this trip. While I was booking the room over the phone for my family ( me, my husband, and our 2 kids 7 and 3 months) they never once mentioned that there is nothing at the hotel and they were under construction. My bad for not checking yelp first. The person who I was talking to was very friendly and the man at check in was great too. No complaints about the staff whatsoever. When we got to our room there was the pack and play that I requested. It didn't have a fitted sheet on it so I was a little apprehensive of letting my little one sleep in there since they just wrapped a regular sheet around it and he's starting to pull things over his face. As I was "inspecting" the pack and play I noticed there was dried spit up (or who knows what) on the mattress part. Needless to say he slept with me. Next, went to the bathroom to find hair on the floor and pee stains on the wall like some man missed after a few too many. So those of you who have traveled with kids know that it's more of a hassle to move everything after you're settled than it's worth so I said F it and we made do. It was only for a night. They did take off the resort fee since there is nothing resort like about the place but I don't think I'll be coming back.

Okay, I'm going to start my review out on the good points and not totally bash the place because after all, it's an older hotel and it's a given that the rooms will be somewhat older and a tad run down, which they were, but you cannot beat this location for the price!  The location is prime, right in the middle of the strip, the center of amazing restaurants, bars and the beautiful new strip walk of Las Vegas.  You can literally walk out the front door and go either way, with New York , NY on one side and the Aria on the other, the Hard Rock and MGM Grand right across the street.  What more could you want?  
The pool area was a fun time, great atmosphere, a DJ playing, great bars and a we truly enjoyed lounging here for a few hours.  We stayed on the strip view side.  It was okay, but you see the top of the casino from this side, which wasn't too great of a sight because it was the roof, but still able to see across to the MGM, Polo Towers, etc.  The casino was pretty much just like all the other casinos, bars here and there, a buffet and a few good restaurants.  The Minus 5 bar is here, which we actually didn't try, but it is a nice edition if you want the experience.  
I did take a star away for the room.  It was run down looking and old, with tape holding up the desk drawer, which was broken and wouldn't stay shut.  Scratches on the wood furniture, cracks in the bathroom tile and a tile piece missing even.  I guess this is what I was expecting because we knew the hotel was older, but we weren't really going to Vegas to spend all day in a luxury room, we were going to Vegas to spend time outside of the room!  Upgrading a few things in the rooms would probably be a plus for this classic hotel, however, I wouldn't complain.  
The hotel staff was great, accommodating and friendly.  The bartender at the pool area was hilarious.  Great service, we would definitely stay here again.

I was so disappointed because I thought that there had been some upgrades since the last time I came which was some 10 years ago. Serious problems with upkeep and cleanliness. The casino floor smells unclean, the pool chairs are DISGUSTINGLY dirty, I bought a mojito by the pool and it had a hair in it  the bathrooms need a new shower head, because the one now has no way of adjusting water pressure and it left my skin all red. The bathroom towels are so old and stiff 
Would not recommend this hotel unless as you read my review you feel this is an upgrade from your last hotel stay. 


Update- I showed pictures and expressed in detail my discontent  to Mr. Thomas Johnson, Management Associate- Hotel Operations. He was very apologetic. 
After several minutes of listening to my concerns he attempted to reach the pool area management via phone but was unsuccessful (they didn't pick up). Mr. Johnson walked over to the pool area and discussed the issues I reported. Mr.Johnson returned and reported he would credit me the resort fees (about $60.00) and that of the pool area bill (approx $60). Honestly it did make me walk away a bit less bitter. 
I heard from bystanders that this hotel is getting a HUGE makeover (something in the millions), hopefully it's true.

The location is the only reason I'd go back to this hotel.

The walls were so paper thin, and in a city like Vegas, there is of course people screaming drunkenly outside the rooms at all hours. 

I requested a non smoking room, but the room next me was apparently not non smoking, because I could smell their smoke every time they lit up. As well as hear their coughing all night long.

This was my first time staying at Monte Carlo over the IHEART weekend.  We stayed for four nights.   I was expecting the worst after the reviews I read but it wasn't that bad.  

We stayed on the 32nd floor in a standard room with a view.  

PRO's.  
GREAT LOCATION
Easy access to Aria\/Bellagio
Starbucks close to the elevators 
The PUB was good 
Easy Check-in\/check out, the guy who checked us in\/out  was extremely nice 
Room service was good, food was ok

CON's
Very small bathroom, no counter space
Tub old and small
Carpet not vacuumed 
room not dusted 
Old rundown furniture, carpet etc... needs updating badly 
Gym to small 
SPA way to small with limited if any amenities ( don't even bother with it) 
Pool way to crowded and needed cleaning 
Poor drink service in casino 
shops close to early 
A\/C in room did not get cold enough 

Well for the price we paid over a busy weekend I guess it wasn't bad, but we won't be staying again until we can get a refurbished room, and then maybe we will try it again.   For now our next visit for December has been booked and we are staying at the Palazzo. Where we will have a generous size bathroom, clean room, and nice amenities.

With all the elite casinos and large new casinos, this place seems outdated.  Small in comparison, this casino just doesn't have the atmosphere of other exciting places.  Having said that, it still is a nice place.  The rooms are nice but basic.  Restaurant choices are limited, but not bad.  Shopping is limited, but a small alley to the Aria offers some choices and cross the strip for some good Vegas souvenirs.  The CVS is next door and is extremely convenient if you stay here.  You can take the tram to Aria and Bellagio, but it's a good hike to get to it.  NY NY is next door but again is a good hike.  Given other casinos in the area, I probably won't stay here again, but there really isn't anything wrong with it.  It just doesn't have the excitement nearby.

I really like the Monte Carlo casino, just try your luck and you might come up. ;)

The rooms are your usual double bed room.  I like the organization of the lobby how all the elevators that lead to the different floors.  BTW, the buffet here is something you could pass on.

I'd definitely stay at the Monte Carlo again. Room service was excellent & considering it's vegas it had a pretty relaxing atmosphere. Not as crazy & loud as most hotels on the strip. Prices also a plus. However, don't expect much of a view; the city center towers over this place.

Almost forgot.......

Please go to the poolside bar and get a Blue Hawaiian, and make sure it's in the football cup. lol. I love it!!

Yes, it's on the strip, but this joint needs a facelift - I'm guessing they tear it down and rebuild in less than five years.  The rooms can be pricey for what you get, and they not top notch.  Good location, mediocre room, and we pairs $350 a night. Not worth it for that price...

I was in here over 10 years ago to see the Lance Burton show (super cool beans magic show by the way), and haven't been back until this past Saturday.  A good friend of mine's was having his wedding there so off we went.  We arrived a few hours early and after getting some grub at the Cafe we did a bit of damage in the casino.  Actually, my mom-in-law did the damage.  As for me, the casino damaged me.  Doh!  The rooms were decent enough.  We all ended up in one of them to take a few shots a down zillions of Chicken McNuggets after the wedding.  Oh, and the Mickey D's there had McRibs!  Scarfed me down a couple of those bad boys too.  =)

I like to book my vacations to Las Vegas using 'Vegas.com'. Whenever you compare prices, Monte Carlo has very competitive if not one of the lowest prices for being in such a great location. It's adjacent to New York New York, which is at one end of the strip. I did notice they charge a $25 daily fee for gym and wifi, which cannot be declined, but even adding that into the package price it's still a deal. You save on time and taxi fees by being in a prime location. If you walk out through the 'Street of Dreams' there's a free tram, that takes you to Aria, and Bellagio - just learned that piece of info this trip. You can thank me later. All in all, an above average place for an average Vegas price.
Good staff with great response time. Very courteous and helpful

The hotel is light, bright, and beautiful. It is NOT as fancy as the Venetian, but definitely better than some others on the strip. Our beds were REALLY comfy and the rooms were immaculate. The Pool area is nice (not the BEST in Vegas) but more than acceptable, palm trees, nice landscaping, a "heated" pool, a wave pool, and a lazy river.  BUT unfortunately (as with MOST Vegas hotels!) we found 1 bedbug in our room! We called guest services and they did not sound surprised, and had us switch rooms right away and comped us a meal ($120). We took ALL the precautions when we arrived back home, and it has been since Tuesday (today is saturday) and still no bites. Google "Las Vegas Hotel Bed Bugs" and you will get a complete list (pretty much every hotel on the strip has had reports). That experience brought my rating down 1 star. If I had to go back to Vegas, I would definitely not mind staying here again (minus the bugs).

I needed a place to stay at for a night in Vegas for two rooms that wasn't hugely expensive - this place is well known for quite awhile. Since Hyatt and MLife hava status match, and I'm Hyatt Diamond, I put a request in for the status match and booked two rooms here.

The lobby is decent here - not over the top but it's decently nice. I didn't see any sort of MLife Platinum check in (maybe I didn't look hard enough). When I got to the gate agent, it turns out my status match never went through. She told me to go to the MLife desk, but never told me that I should come back once I do the match. It's my understanding that I could have been upgraded rooms. Nope, they never even offered.

The rooms themselves were not bad, but pretty outdated. The hallways near it had carpet that looked like it was neglected. There were parts of the hotel that were like that really. The casino wasn't bad either. There's absolutely no perks for even breakfast for MLife Platinum members. Only higher bonuses and the VIP cab line. That's it - and that's kind of depressing.

I'd say "I wouldn't recommend staying here", which I wouldn't really unless you just need an OK room for a night or two but they're apparently going to renovate the entire place soon for the next 1.5 years. Would be interested to see what it looks like after.

Shout out to the two bell guys (one from Chicago and one from Hawaii) that were really helpful with our luggage.

For what we paid, this was good value. I've paid much more for a comparable room at Caesars Palace, so I was happy here. I've outlined the pros and cons below. We just had a one-night stay (Thursday), but for $48 plus resort fee (MLife rate) it was worthwhile. The room was simple, but spacious. The furnishings were a bit dated and worn, but it was fine.  The hotel's branding calls it "Unpretentiously Luxurious." Depending on your perception of luxury, that is a pretty fair slogan.

On the meh side, the HD tv featured no HD channels. The shower is not well lit, but the bathroom was clean and functional. The check-in took about 30 minutes in  line and there were only 3 or 4 employees manning the desks, though there were stations for something like 15. If you are MLife gold or higher, look for the VIP services on the edge of the lobby toward the casino to check in.

We were upgraded to a Strip View room (27th floor of 32). The view of the Strip was minimal; you'll be mostly looking across to MGM Grand and Signature along with some of the lowest rent shops along the strip, or you'll be looking north at the towering Mandarin Oriental which blocks any view further up the Strip. I should have taken a photo to show you, but I didn't even think about it because it was so unremarkable. It was not a view worth paying for, but again, our upgrade was free. If this will be your first trip to Las Vegas and you really want a nice view of the Strip, look for another hotel.

My biggest complaint was that the people on our floor were loud in the hallways in the middle of the night. Yeah, it's Vegas, but have some decency. That's what I get for trying to stay on a cheap rate, I guess.

The best part was the pool. With a lazy river and a wave pool, you get a lot of options. The pool wasn't massive, but it needn't be. The water temperature was nice and the music was good. A DJ came in the afternoon and she mixed good songs but didn't become the center of attention of our afternoon at the pool.

The casino offers some $5 blackjack tables near the food court which is a nice option for the risk-averse or the parsimonious Yelper. Most of the other tables were $10 or $15, I think.

The Cafe was a good lunch spot for not too much coin. I had a nice ham and cheese sandwich with salt and vinegar chips and my wife enjoyed her meal, too. I can't remember what it was, but she liked it. Food here counts toward MLife points. It didn't seem to count at the Dragon Noodle house, but that was another good lunch option. The lunch specials are cheap but the food quality was much better than Panda Express.

Though the view in our room was meh, the hotel's location is good to many other hotels. You can catch the tram for a quick ride up to Bellagio if you're in the mood for something fancier.  With the cheap room rate and convenience to other hotels, this would be a good place to stay on the cheap if you want to spend your money on nice dinners and\/or shows. There are cheaper hotels in the MLife family, but they get really, really sketchy (Luxor, Excalibur). Mirage or Mandalay Bay would be a notch up from Monte Carlo.

Another random note: Monte Carlo is one of the easiest to access from Las Vegas Blvd. That is, the driveway is not as complicated. This was a good advantage for us because my brother (a local) picked us up when he got back into town for the weekend. Also, being on the south end of the Strip makes it a  pretty quick to\/from the airport.

In all, I had a good stay at the Monte Carlo.  Compared to other hotels on the Las Vegas Strip, the Monte Carlo has central access to elevators and attractions.  The rooms were well kept and clean.  They didn't have free Wi-Fi access but you could plug into an Ethernet cable if you need to access the Internet in your room.  The price for the room was reasonable as well.  However, a hotel room is really only for sleeping in Las Vegas.

They have a casino, of course, along with various restaurants, a small shopping corridor and the Blue Man Group.  If you have a chance to see the Blue Man Group, do it, because it's a fun and interactive show.  The Monte Carlo should be lucky that they are able to have this show at their casino.
