The rooms are still comfortable, clean, everything works like it should, but you can tell from looking at the furniture that it's time for a renovation to keep up with the competition.

Anyway, to sum up, I am headed back to the MC soon, and am looking forward to another good experience.  Like I said, all of the staff I interacted with were very professional and helpful, and the drink service on the casino floor was above average as well.  

Worth the 4 stars for the service and experience.  3 stars for the rooms, which are about to get the attention they need.  Overall, rounded up to 4 and am looking forward to staying here again.

Overall the stay was ok. The hotel had a great food court but the rooms are beginning to look a bit dated. The buffet food was not very good at all and tasted old to my daughter and I. The price was very affordable and staff was all very nice.

This really was about to be a 2 star review, but an upgrade saved the day. Regardless, I'm still pretty disappointed in the Monte Carlo.

I was actually married at the Monte Carlo in 2006, and had a huge suite. I'd only been back to visit friends who stayed there a couple of times over the years, and thought it was ok for the price point and of course the location is great.

So, when I checked in, I had relatively high hopes. I knew it wasn't going to be the Wynn, but I didn't expect a run down, old room, where the furniture was chipped, scuffed, and everything (except for the flat screen tv) looked just worn. It was seriously like staying in a Red Roof Inn. I was doubly disappointed because the check in agent went on and on about how great the room was and how he hooked me up. Uh, no. The room hasn't been updated since the Monte Carlo opened, I'm sure- and it showed.

I sat on the bed and just knew I'd be upset if I stayed in that room, given it was supposed to be a birthday "staycation"- a gift to myself. I called the front desk to express my disappointment. The agent handled it well and offered to upgrade me to a junior suite for $30. Done.

The junior suite was MUCH nicer-  the decor was more modern, the room was huge- nice living room area, mini fridge (no microwave or mini bar, oddly), big bathroom, great view, and even a half bath at the entrance. My only real complaints with this room was that there were no outlets near the bed\/nightstands, and they provided very few towels. Otherwise, it was a good room and a huge improvement. 

So, the Monte Carlo saved their rating, but seriously, update those rooms. I know this isn't a 5 star property, but they should be a bit ashamed of themselves and the condition of the regular rooms.

I have to say, I really liked this place. It's a convenient location on the strip. It's not too bad on the price front. It's connected to the tram system. The room was a good a decent size; there were four of us in a 2 queen bed room. It didn't have an amazing view, but it was decent. The food court was standard; I appreciate that they had Subway as a choice rather than just things like McDonalds. There were other places to eat in the hotel, but I didn't get to try those out. 

There are a few bars as well, not a surprise there, but I did have my own personal favorite one, the Ignite Lounge. It was favorite because there were awesome bartenders that got to know me and always had awesome drinks. I would just say, "Make me something strong and fruity," my standard order, and they would come back with something new and yummy. And they got to know me and my friend and would look out for us.  

Also, I have to say, I enjoyed their pool scene as well. It's not a pool party that one can get at places like Wet, EBC or Rehab. But it's not bad; it's chill and there's still a good mix of people there.
We had a spectacular view from our room, overlooking MGM and the strip. Other than that, the room was pretty average. Nothing fancy, but at least it was spacious and clean.
Casino is good, lots of eateries but wouldn't mind booking a room here!!! Maybe next time...

We recently spent a week at the Monte Carlo on an upper floor in a spa suite.  The check in line was short. The staff was friendly and attentive, especially the maid, who literally organized all my makeup brushes that I had strewn about.  The room itself was old school Vegas, a wet bar and a tufted headboard, even outdated lamps and wallpaper.  We didn't go to the wave pool or lazy river, but they looked fun.

However... the subtracted star is almost worth subtracting all of the stars due to the gross nature of the issue.  On our last night before we headed to dinner we called maintenance because the toilet was clogged. (The toilet had crazy water pressure, but somehow was stopped up) When we returned the toilet had been repaired, however... there was raw sewage in several places.  On the toilet seat, on the floor near the toilet room door, on the towel we had placed on the floor to help prevent us from slipping out of the shower... mostly drops, but UGH I wanted to just bleach the entire suite after that.

You cannot beat the location of the Monte Carlo.  It's so conveniently located on the strip, and the trams make it even better.
However...
- Cheap room, I think we paid $80 for a Friday night
- Incredibly long line for check in
- Good parking lot, but bad signage on where to enter.  We had to ask someone and pull a couple U turns
- Lots of construction going on
- Hallway to our room reeked of puke, and I'm pretty sure we spotted a large stain, though it had been cleaned up.  Turned out the puker ended up in our room and left a little trail on the bed's dust ruffle. Thankfully, we were able to switch rooms, and Thelma, the security officer, let us into our new room until our keys were activated.  Thanks, Thelma!
- Room was very average and bare bones.  Bathroom showed age of the hotel: rusty bath spout, no soap dish, not much counter space for toiletries
- Good shower pressure at least!
- No fridge in the room, but I did find a safe as we were getting ready to leave
- Not enough outlets to charge all our devices  
- Pools looked nice, with a small lazy river, but we didn't get to partake  
- Very thin walls; you will hear all the toilets around you flushing and lots of talking in the hallway

DO NOT STAY HERE - They charge a resort fee. There is NO POOL. They very cordially invite you to use Mandalay Bay or MGM pool. These pools are not close. On top of that there is no enforcement of their no smoking policy.  I am next to a room where cigar smoke is prevalent. It is disgusting.  Never again.

This wasn't my first time staying at the Monte Carlo and it probably won't be my last, but will be until the construction is completed on this hotel. We stayed here in April 2017 and returned September 2017. What a difference a few months can make! Half the casino was boarded up, the buffet closed the day after our arrival, and the construction was atrocious. We were on the 7th floor and were woken up to jack hammering at 9 am. Sounded like it was coming right through our bathroom walls. I didn't complain about it because I understand that this will happen with construction. Went to ask for late check out in the wee hours of the morning and was helped by Mary. She was very helpful and gave us our late check out for free. Also mentioned the construction, but not to be a complainer but just to say it out loud (I'm sure they receive quite a few complaints throughout the day), and she was kind enough to give us some free comps as well. 

Since there isn't a pool, we used the free shuttle to head on over to Mandalay Bay for a day. HIGHLY recommend it! 

I give this 4 for now but will be happy to update once I stay here again. I hear the Monte Carlo will soon be a 5-star resort and fully updated soon!

The cleaning staff and employees around the casino were the best thing about this hotel .. The food at Brand, their steakhouse was horrible .. Don't eat there, unless you want food poisoning .. You would think that Monte Carlo would be lavish with the name, look and logo of it all... But the room was small.. Smaller then Luxor.. We also ordered room service two days . .. The food was worse than hospital food .. I would never come here again .. Thoroughly disappointed ..heed my words ..

Location, location, location!  Everything about this hotel points to its central location on the strip.  The hotel itself I'd probably give 3.5 stars, but the location makes it easily worth it.

After nearly 20 years, the Monte Carlo is definitely showing its age, especially compared to some of the newer resorts on the strip.  However, that doesn't mean that it's bad.  Just don't expect to see all of the newest amenities in your room.  The only thing that really made me go "meh" was the shower head, but the rest of the room was just fine.  I didn't have the problem with thin walls that others experienced.  Oh yeah, and at $60 per night, the room was basically a steal.

Overall, it was a great night's sleep, and you can't beat being able to walk basically anywhere, not to mention the tram service to CityCenter and the Bellagio.

Terrible hotel rooms. Stained walls, ceiling and chair. Carpet in rooms and hallway coming up at seams, beds looked were old and lumpy. Towels looked like rags. Their idea of a duvet was several layers of sheets wrapped around a blanket.  Mold in tub and ceiling. Old hard water stains all over faucets. Lamps not working. Sadly, about 100 of my friends experienced the same room conditions. Was bumped to this property due to MGM convention deal and being oversold. I have been to Vegas too many times to count. This hotel was disgusting. Room service carts left in hallway for hours on end. None of us could believe this hotel is on the main strip. About par with the Stratosphere or your local Motel. I bought 2 cans of Lysol and sprayed down everything. Vegas fail. #mlife needs to get this property off!

From the old school music playing, to the 35-45 year crowd cruising the joint drunk (myself included), to the smoke infested gaudy chandelier clad casino with the air pumped full of grandma's perfume to cover up the smoke infested smell, everything about this place screamed 1992 (or 1996 when this place opened).  I was so disappointed.

Fast forward to the next morning, and it looked so much better.  It still smelled like grandma's perfume on top of tons of smoke but the people were chill, the staff were friendly, and in the end, you get what you pay for.  Since internet rates are super cheap, you really can't be disappointed...  

...unless you stay at Hotel 32 and pay premium prices for what you thought was a upscale boutique hotel within the Monte Carlo....EPIC FAIL! Review to follow.  

Otherwise, there's a little bit of everything, and works well for the budget minded.  Heck, I hear there's even a lazy river out back that you can take advantage of during the triple digit summers.

My husband and I stayed at the Monte Carlo for the second time a couple of weeks ago.  It is not the most happening place but it is clean and the staff is great.  A couple of new eateries since the last time we visited were a nice a surprise -- didn't have to leave the hotel to get my gelato or morning coffee!

Bad service
Pubic hair and make up on "clean" towel
Dirty room
3 out of 3 restaurants on property
Delivered sub-standard food quality and service.
Insect in bed (see photo)
Will never return.
Enough said.

free...  companion passes from my flight attendant sister
+
good timing... no school or work during Winter Break
+
$50... rates for a standard room with 2 queens at the Monte Carlo midweek in mid-December
+
free MC $30 food credit and $20 free play... holler!  
+
$80...  money won from 5 cent and 25 cent slots
=
priceless:  the satisfaction and freedom of having a totally fun and cheap-a$$ night in vegas with sis before the chaos of the holidays.

Have stayed at multiple places in Vegas.  The Wynn, TI, Mandalay, Bellagio, Mirage etc.   I have grown accustomed to things being up to date, clean and good service.    Obviously the Wynn will be nicer than TI.  So I handicap the quality with the price.    We paid $230 (before fees and taxes) a night for Monte Carlo.  It became very obvious early in to our stay that I paid way over the property's relative value.   Nothing terrible or disgusting occurred, but everything was sub par.      Pay the extra $50 a night and don't make my mistake.

I have not been to Vegas in a long time, in short I must say this is probably the worst hotel I ever stayed at, the pool is under construction which we were not told about, they give you the option to take a shuttle to the pool at the MGM Grand or the Mondalay Bay Resort, which is a huge inconvenience... decided to do so only to find out that you have to walk literally a mile in for the casino just to get to the pool,  which was extremely crowded and full of drunk people, a very ghetto looking type... the hotel still insisted in charging $39 Resort fee... for what nobody knows... needless to say I will never stay at this hotel again.

Recently stayed here for a brief overnight on our way into the desert. Unbelievable how dirty the Room was. The bathroom had crap on the mirror and gunk on the faucet. The walls were filthy as well as the shower. The shower head looked like it had been duct taped to the wall and several of the towels had holes in them. 
The glasses were so dirty that I wouldn't even drink out of them after we washed them. The bed was my favorite part. There were staines on almost every piece of linen. I had to strategically position the sheets so my g\/f would notice or we would have been trying to change rooms at 1 am. I honestly cannot understand how or why a place would even bother operating at such a low level.

The hotel overall was good but I was disappointed in the complete lack of responsibility or concern for their customers. My friend forgot her bag in a cab with her passport in it and she requested security to go over the cameras to give her a cab number (there are thousands of cabs in Vegas and each company told us to get a cab number). Security spent about 5 mins and told us that we were not on camera. I went to Flamingo, where I was originally picked up by the cab and they took an hour helping me and I wasn't even a paying guest. I basically did the job for the security at Monte Carlo and 4 hours later when I went back with information, I guess there was a miracle and they finally spotted us on the camera. Their security team had complete disrespect for us and actually told us that they had already done us a favour of looking through the tapes once and actually sighed when we told them that we had a description. Top that up with the creeps they let hang around in the hotel inviting you to open bars. This isn't really a family hotel or a friendly hotel. Stay at the Flamingo instead at least know how to provide customer service.

I want to give it 2.5 stars because my trip was simply amazing and it made up for the fact the hotel sucked. I went Fourth of July weekend... (yay for tourist weekend... NOT)

Arrived at hotel around 2am, tired, and ready to just collapse on the bed.  Opened the door to a room that wasn't even CLEANED. I felt like an intruder. Never in my life has that happened to me, not even at a lowly Motel 6. Wow just wow. Well, they gave us a different room and $50 in hotel 'bucks'.  It wasn't my choice particularly to stay here, but everyone else wanted to.  It's definitely old and not up to par with all the newer hotels in the area.  My fave hotel is MGM so I'll compare everything to that. The restaurants at Monte Carlo was unimpressive :( 

The bathrooms need dire remodeling... can't complain so much about the rooms... the point is to stay there as little as possible lol. One thing is I did really enjoy was the pool. That weekend reached 118 degrees so the pool was amazing.  It's like that idea of wandering in the desert for days on end and seeing an oasis in the distance. Yah, the Monte Carlo pool was really like that for us.  Didn't want to hit up Wet republic and surround myself with douches so this pool really did it.The crowd was just right, chill and mellow, and the music was great.  Pool and party are two words i really really really agree with. Oh and bronzed life guard, will you walk by a few more times again? ;)

I stayed here before the renovations began and found the rooms and public areas to be quite tired and, indeed, in need of a refresh. 

Inside, the rooms weren't nasty or in dire shape, but you could tell that the furnishings, decor, and bathroom were quite dated. Then again, I wasn't really willing to splurge on my recent stay here, so the beaten-up surroundings came with the territory. It was simply an OK place to crash for a couple of nights.

Here's hoping the renovations bring this property back up to par.

We booked Monte Carlo Hotel because it says 4 star hotel everywhere. We were very excited to take our guest over to Las Vegas. This was their first time in Vegas. We checked into the hotel and everything looked very nice until we got into our room. It was HORRIBLE,  worst than Motel 6. I stayed at Cesar Palace before and thought it would be the same. There is no refrigrator in the room and bathroom looked so old like from the 80's. I mean EVRYTHING was horrible. I wouldn't complaint if i paid $100 a night but i end up paying almost $350 for two nights for a place i hated. On top of everything when i booked a room they didn't say anything about the $8 parking per day. There are no special amenities that we pay $30 plus resort fee for. We wanted to go to the gym and it was closed when we got there around 11pm. Pool is so tiny and not very nice. STAY AWAY. And Starbucks charged us $7.95 for Tall Chai Tea Latte plus .80 cent for Extra Shot which made my Tall Chai Tea Latte $8.25 and when i asked a question the manager gave me very weird look and argued with me that Tall Chai Tea Latte is $4.95 plus .80 cent for the extra shot is $8.25. Really? Stay Away. I wish i can get my money back. NEVER AGAIN.

My husband and I really liked this hotel. It is right in the middle of everything.  The room was nice.  We were able to get one on the 27th floor without having to do the $20 card trick, so that was pretty cool.  Also checked in an hour before actual check in time of 3 and it was no problem at all. Would definitely stay here again!

I've stayed at Monte Carlo before, but this experience was not that great... 

I don't understand why you can't even bring outside food or drinks into the pool area when they have their own food court in the hotel... I bought a drink and a banana from the Starbucks in the hotel and the pool girl told me no outside food or drinks.... so i brought my drink back to my room then came back down... i totally forgot i had my banana in my bag when i got down to the pool, so she searched my bag and then the same pool girl rudely said, you can't bring that banana in there, so i went to the side and ate it... 

 finally i was in the pool area getting a towel and i asked for 2 and a different pool girl said 1 towel per person while the person before me just asked for 4 towels and she gave them to him... it's like be consistent... if you're going to give 1 towel per person then just do that, don't give 1 guest 4 towels and another 1 towel.

they expect you to buy food and drinks poolside, but you can't even get service... my friends and i waited about an hour for the waitress to come to us... my friend had to ask her twice and he also asked if there was another place we could order from and of course there wasn't... so we got tired of waiting almost 2 hours without service that we just packed up and left the pool area...

another incident i had in the pool area was another guest and his daughter were coming in as i was leaving and the same pool girl at the entrance told them they couldn't being a stinking bottled of water into the pool area... it's like what the heck, it's just a bottled water?!?!?!

all in all, if you're gonna stay at the Monte Carlo for the pool area... don't do it, it's not worth it... i don't think I'd stay here again because the reason why i go to Vegas is for the pool, the nightlife, and the gambling and since the pool area sucks then this hotel is out of the question....

Got over booked when I came here so I was lucky enough to get upgraded to one of their new "all natural" rooms. They're pretty nice ! There's some cool new features that they added into the room. The mirror in the bathroom has an energy button & pressing it makes the light that perfect bright selfie quality lol ! The shower omg *heart eyes* ! Some of the hotels have those old shower heads where the water hits you way too hard & if you adjust it it's no better. This was one I could sit on the floor & sleep ! Plus there's a vitamin c attachment on it to keep your skin feeling great! I did wish there was a bath tub tho, getaways are the best times to bust out those bath bombs & I'm glad i didn't bring them or I would have been so sad ! 

The bed was SUPER COMFY ugh I would have stayed an extra day just to sleep in that bed if I could have. There's some cool new features with the lighting to make the room feel more relaxed. PLUS YOU CAN MAKE THE WHOLE ROOM PINK. I don't know why but it's great lol ! There's an air humidifier & some other fancy thing on the wall. Idk what that thing did but it was fun to mess with lol ! 

Overall the new rooms are pretty nice & the lobby is also going through some big renovations. Can't wait to see it when its done!

Nice rooms & very helpful staff. When we checked in the lady was very accommodating. Our room wasn't ready but she gave us our keys & a map & asked for our number. They sent a txt with our room number as soon as it was ready. I loved it here.

This is my favorite casino in Las Vegas, because it smells the best, it's quiet, I like the walkways, and I won the most money here. There's just something about this casino that calms me. There's not a ton of people walking towards me, and it's not overwhelming.

I'm going to have to agree with the masses about the Monte Carlo. It's nice but doesn't have as much character as some of the other casinos on the strip. The Bellagio, Venetian & the Wynn just to name a few, are all beautiful and have more to offer than the Monte Carlo. I got a room complimentary here for the last 2 days of my trip and I have to say it's nicer than the Imperial Palace. Which casino isn't though?

I checked in, dropped my bags off and chilled at the pool area. They had a lazy river and a wave pool which I took advantage of which was nice. After the pool, I did a little poker at the poker room for a couple of hours before I met up with my group for dinner and drinks!

Another average hotel on the strip. Maybe a little nicer than average.

The basic conditions that everyone wants from a hotel room are that it is clean, quiet, and comfortable. We experienced one out of three. The room was ordinary and did not live up to the photos on their website. It looked worn, and the housekeeping was sloppy. There was a large stain on the sheet, and the mirrors were dirty. They forgot several items, like the ice bucket and soap for the shower. The drapery pull came off in my hand. Worst of all, there is construction happening across the street, and each morning we woke up to the incessant beeping of the back-up warning for several construction vehicles before seven o'clock. Also, we could hear too much noise in the hallway and from nearby rooms. On the plus side, the bed was comfortable and the lobby is nice. We usually travel to Vegas once a year. This was the first time we stayed at the Monte Carlo, and we were very disappointed. Obviously, we won't return.

I consider this to now be a value hotel. The hotel shows its age in the hallways and rooms. The carpets have spots on them. The elevators are scratched up. BUT... the place is cheap, and there seem to be quite a few people with kids, compared to a few years ago. And it's easy to get to the food court, for the folks with kids or on a budget. 

The bars have all new decor, and the "HIT" bar featured the best Mai Tai I've had - original 1944 Victor Bergernon recipe.

There's easy access to free parking  in the Self Park lot. The staff are quite patient and friendly. But there's no fridge in the room, and the large old TV is rather depressing.

Another Yelper suggested renovated upper floors, but this does not apply to the "Higher Floor Deluxe". These are the same standard rooms, but just on a higher floor. The Front Desk guy hinted that the renovations would begin in 2011 or 2012.

Overall, for folks looking to just party and not looking for pampering and opulence, Monte Carlo provides a central place on the Strip to set up camp, and crash at.
The brunch buffet on saturdays is way too pricey for the selection and the quality is simply average. Will not be eating here again.

Stayed at the Monte Carlo over the weekend because I had comp'ed rooms.  I would not pay to stay here.  Although the casino itself is nice, the room was bad.  My biggest complaint is the walls are super thin.  You can hear people talking and walking in the halls, you can hear muffled conversations of the people in the rooms adjacent to you.  You can also hear all the water in the pipes whenever another room flushes a toilet or showers.  On my last day, a Monday, there was construction in our hall and you could hear banging and drilling.  If I wasn't leaving first thing in the morning, I would've have been extremely upset by the noise.

This is being generous due to the pool and its location on the Strip.  For a hotel named after one of the most glamorous places in the world, the Monte Carlo could seriously use a bit of a makeover.  Rooms were a decent size, but bathroom could use an update, the TV could have HD, and for the resort fee Wi-Fi or at least a working internet connection in the room would have been helpful.  I really loved the pool, and the food and drinks there were not bad.  Diablo's at the front of the hotel was nice and the happy hour specials were good.  Not my favorite place on the strip and I probably wouldn't stay there again but you could definitely do a lot worse.

Cons:
Not enough outlets
No refrigerator 
No coffee maker
Bare room - nothing special 
Noisy and not sound proof rooms 
Not enough chairs at the pool
Long check in lines- on a Friday there was only 3 people checking people in...

Pro: 
Pool was nice- lazy river and wave pool
Good prices
They did listen to request of having our rooms connected. 

I go to Vegas a few times a year and have stayed at other M Life hotels. This by far was my least favorite so I will not be going back.

Pretty nice hotel with a great location right next to the new casinos and the City Center. If you want an affordable, clean room, which puts you right on the strip then the Monte Carlo serves that purpose.

Took some bad advice to stay at the Monte Carlo hotel. It's a hotel at the end of the strip, and it's one the oldest hotels in the strip. I've stayed at three star hotels in third world countries that were better than this. 

The cons:
- terrible location and a far walk from most things on the strip 
- the whole place stinks of cigarettes masked with a vanilla scent 
- crappy pool area that does not compare to the pools in the other hotels 
- poor water pressure, water not hot enough 
- crappy toiletries 

The one pro and only saving grace:
- it's connected to the free tram that runs through Aria and Bellagio, (and a short walk to Caesar's Palace from Bellagio) 

If I were to go back to Vegas, I would stay in one of the other newer hotels.  Both Bellagio and Caesar's Palace has really nice pools.

Update: I got someone to fix the water pressure, so that was good. I extended my stay by an extra day and paid $82. By 9pm the manager was knocking at the door asking why we haven't checked out yet and our key cards were deactivated even though we paid for the room until the next morning. I did not complain because I was on my way out already.

I stayed at this hotel just recently and I really enjoyed my stay. The rooms are clean and spacious. The hotel itself is neat and there is always people there to help you with anything you need. 

My friend and I decided to go to the pool party when we got there. It was really cool! They have a lazy river which makes it fun to have a drink and hand out. They also have the pool which is pretty big and with warm water. There is a full bar and they also have music playing the entire time. 

The casino is clean and the cocktail waitresses are fast and they bring you exactly what you ask for. My friend and I were playing and this man came and asked us if we would want to be part of the players club; which allows you to get discounts and special offers. That was really nice of him (:

Overall I liked this resort and in the future will most likely book a room here.

The rates are good but in serious need of room upgrades! We got the spa suite and it was pretty gross. It smelled like mildew and there was mold in the shower. Didn't get in the tub because the jets looked really dirty. The carpet is gross. Wallpaper was peeling off everywhere. We ended up changing rooms from the spa suite to a reg room because I couldn't handle the mildew smell. Doesn't look like the pictures at all! We also couldn't check in until 5! When check in is 3 and check out is 11. That was very annoying. The customer service sucked at the front desk as well. Won't be back here

I am so sad. I did not know that the Mote Carlo was no longer a modern property. I booked directly on their website. It appears that I was charged excessively more than other methods of reservation.
It is what it is; an 80s era Holiday Inn. The furnishings are old and tired. The staff is as friendly as can be expected; each of the people I encountered appeared to be in on the joke.

I specifically booked to stay at the Monto Carlo due to a show at the Park Theater. The artist became ill and  the show was cancelled. If this had been communicated when known rather than waiting a day, I would have canceled my trip instead of staying here with little to do,

The resort fee is amusing; this is not a resort. The rooms are spartan and the carpeting is horrifying. I hope that this property is upgraded and I wish the employees well.

Find another more modern, customer focused property.

We waited for forty minutes to check in as angry and tired travelers sauntered through the common feeder line like livestock at half the speed of smell, to speak with one of the four uninterested people at the counter whose job is to check in a maximum of three guests per half hour and then go on what I assume is a seventy five minute break.  We waited another thirty minutes to get our key fixed on day three, since apparently their 1984 commodore vic-20 computer system can't handle something as ridiculously complicated as a comp'd room.  Silly us.  

The lobby was not full of vultures accosting people and trying to give away "free shows" - presumably because they'd be beaten to death by management for being too helpful, so that was nice.  The convenience store sells 20 oz bottles of soda for $4.50 and bottled starbucks beverages for more than it costs to take a cab to Seattle and buy one there.  I can only surmise that the inflated price is to offset the cost of not refrigerating the beverages - Ive literally produced colder urine.

The casino is fairly nice and the machines all work, but the cocktail waitresses evidently have the same break schedule as the staff at the checkin counter.  In order to get a free drink in that casino, you basically need to get up on the roulette table and start taking your clothes off while dancing to Usher and Pitbull songs.  Unfortunately I forgot my leopard print g string at home and was wearing tighty whiteys so the best I could do was a Pepsi.  

Stay at another hotel.

For the price it was great (keep in mind we had a comp'd room fro the weekend from MyVegas)! Love the location and as I have only visited once before and stayed elsewhere I thought the location really made this a great place to stay. Loved the fact that we weer able to take the tram from the Monte Carlo all the way to the Bellagio (AWESOME!) and it was a short walk to the Paris (for dinner) and cab ride to the Luxor for Blue Man Group. Also close to the NYNY for Zumanity. There was construction still ongoing but we didn't have any noise issues. Checkout was easy peasy although getting out of the parking structure was difficult (some sort of malfunction with reading the passes to get your car out). Overall, I would stay here again. The rooms are standard but that's not what Vegas is for (limited TV channels which was irritating as my drunken-self likes to watch TV to sober up but there was a Star Wars marathon on so I was a-ok!).

We stayed in a suite for Saturday through Tuesday night over Labor Day weekend. 

It's not a particularly bad hotel. But it's not particularly great one either. Overall, we're left with three impressions: 
1) the accountants are in control
2) the place is losing money
3) maybe we should have spent a little more to get a little more. 

Most of the staff (check-in, check-out, valet, maids, bell service) was terrific. On the other hand, there was no cocktail service at the gaming tables in the wee hours of the morning. 

We tried both the buffet and the caf, both had good food and mediocre service. 

The Lobby Starbucks came in handy: though we had a suite, there was no coffee maker in the room, nor was it possible to get one from housekeeping. 

Other stuff that should have been included:  
* gym $19\/day
* Internet $14.99\/day. 

We'd originally selected the Monte Carlo because it has a 400 foot long "Lazy River." 400 feet sounds like a pretty long river, until you realize that with over 3000 rooms, the hotel hosts over 6000 guests.  Do the math: that's more than 15 guests per foot of river. The rest of the pool's facilities are similarly undersized. 

The result is that for the limited hours the pool area is open (9a-7p), the pool's facilities are too crowded for comfort. We bumped and got bumped enough by other people in the river that we left after an hour or two, never returning throughout our five-day stay. 

The hotel, like many large businesses, handles most things with highly optimized efficiency. And by things, I mean "guests." 

We don't wanna be "things." We wanna be valued guests staying in a premier hotel on the world-famous Las Vegas strip, even if part of why we chose the hotel was its affordability. 

I had a hard time putting my finger on why the stay at the hotel was so unremarkable, but a book I recently read (The Designful Company, by Marty Neumeier) raises an interesting theory (see: http:\/\/tinyurl.com\/m4qgro).

In it, the author suggests that businesses cannot continue to make themselves more efficient and profitable if they are to succeed and grow. Instead, they need to find authentic ways to connect with target audiences. 

The best and most memorable parts of our vacation took place outside the hotel. 

Why would we return?


--------

Late update: The Monte Carlo just hit me with an ad promising a coffee maker with the room. Apparently, it's not enough to rent a suite. You have to rent a suite in the Monte Carlo's "Hotel 32." 

According to the ad, the coffee maker's name is "Sara." I'm almost afraid to ask. 
http:\/\/www.montecarlo.com\/offers\/2009\/08_hotel32_guestbook\/

Unbelievable.  Charged me 25 dollars extra for a NEW room. I reserved a room and when i got to the hotel,i was asked to pay extra 25 dollars if i want to be in the new remodeled room. I could not believe it. I accepted... however, the smell of the room is so strong tbat i get headaches... smells like the glue the put on new fresh carpets.

We were in Vegas for a wedding and got a decent deal on the Monte Carlo. In general, the hotel was decent. Great location, good food options in the hotel itself. But I had a few gripes:

Check-In: Holy crap, get some more people up front to check people in! We arrived just before 2:30 and the line was already fairly long. It took us over a half hour to check in. There were only 3 people working the check-in, while there were 3 or 4 people working the concierge\/check-out line next door--with no one in line! Friends of ours showed up a few hours later and stood in line for over an hour to check in because there was only ONE person checking people in. Not acceptable. And when we finally checked in, we were told there were no more king beds available until the following day. Fine, whatever. Except our friends who checked in later that night got a king bed! 

Cleanliness\/Comfort: The rooms are old, outdated, and dingy. The old carpets were covered in stains. The beds were low and lumpy (although the pillows were soft). There was hair on the bathroom floor that clearly didn't belong to us. We also found a couple of bugs in our room.

If it weren't for the two issues above, I would have given this place 4 stars.

I have to be in Vegas for my friend's wedding and there is the iHeart music festival going on, so we went with the cheapest four star hotel on the Strip.

Long story short, $240 a night is a complete rip-off, I have stayed in Comfort Inn that has better room than this place, I mean, no refrigerator for a four star hotel ? Are you shitting me ?

And I really hope their housekeeping crew enjoy my gift,
two hours after I check out I found out that I left something in the night stand,
call their Lost and Found Dept and report the room number and location of the item well before the earliest check in time,
10 days later now and they still told me item not found, makes me wonder who gets their hand on it.

Conveniently located, easy parking and comfortable rooms. The bathroom looked a bit tired, but I didn't plan to spend a lot of time in there... :)

No wifi. I was very surprised by this, especially considering the "resort fee" they tack onto the room rate.

We asked for a regular non-smoking room and we were sent into a smoking room. When we went into the room, it immediately shocked me that the room was as outdated as the Paris Hotel. The dcor was certainly unpleasant and unEuropean to say the least. Also, the room was not clean and I couldn't even look at it. I noticed that there was a minor floor crack by the window and that was just unacceptable. This hotel is rated a "AAA 4-Diamond Hotel", which is basically saying that this hotel is in the same class as Mirage (Another 4-Diamond Hotel). The Monte Carlo is far from that rating. I wouldn't pass this hotel above 2 Diamonds, but I do like the name of this hotel.

Monte Carlo, a great name, and a great disappointment.

Great value, lots of choices.
Rooms aren't super-luxe, but adequate.  I think we got a low rate due to the construction next door, which never bothered us anyway.

Pros:
- Great rates for rooms
- Lazy river & wave pool are super fun & family-friendly
- Food court including a Subway & Starbucks inside the hotel.  I loved having my routine creature-comfort food there instead of having to pay for a gourmet meal every time I ate.
- Located right next to New York, New York (where our Cirque 
du Soleil show was) and within walking distance of the Miracle Mile & other casinos

Cons:
- When we checked in & went up to our room, there was a family already inside.  WTH?  Because of it, we were upgraded to basically the same room, but with a better view.
- Room smelled like smoke.  It's Vegas.  What are ya gonna do?
- No free wifi?? Boo.
Really nice casino, I am just reviewing the slot gaming. They have a nice, small slot section, plenty of different games, low key, pennies to high limit gaming, and the payouts were ok.

There are plenty of hotel\/resorts to stay at on the Las Vegas Strip... Monte Carlo is in the top running for one of the best places to stay on the CHEAP.

The rooms are normal, slightly dated. Nothing fancy yet you also don't feel like you're at a cheap motel. 

One of the best parts of this hotel is the pool area. Various pools, spas, and a lazy river! Plus, you don't have to wait ridiculous lines or have a promoter get you in. It's a low key yet still a fun pool... perfect to spend a hot Vegas day.

Perks
Pool area
Free WiFi
Normal rooms


Overall, if you are in need of a place on the strip to stay for minimal $, Monte Carlo will not disappoint.

The casinos location is nice on the strip.  However, I did not get ANY points or credits for playing for several hours in their poker room... even though I had opened my account there!  Mlife's customer service also did not help me with this.  Their pit boss was also rude when I had asked him a question.  Whats more, their jacuzzi was running at lukewarm temprature!

Because there are so many hotel-casino choices in Las Vegas, each one targets a subtly different market niche; this one is where tourists who want the euro swank feel of places like Bellagio, Paris and Venetian *but aren't willing to pay for it* come to stay.  Well, the old adage "you get what you pay for" is certainly true here.  This place is very mediocre, from the Holiday Inn style rooms, to the disingenuous service, to the disappointing buffet, which actually used to be pretty good.  Certainly the best aspect of this hotel is its ideal mid-Strip location.  For the money, the Luxor is a much better bet (no pun intended).

Disappointed with this hotel. Not only was the carpet stained in our room, but there was an ethernet cord and the wifi almost never worked. First of all.... what's an ethernet cord???????? As I'm from Canada it's costly to have my phone on so I do rely on wireless, the ethernet cord basically made my phone an ipod touch. Baring this the front desk, and room service were extremely unhelpful when we were tying to get a cork screw. They wanted to charge us $3 to have the bottle opened, but wouldn't be able to do it for at least 40 minutes. When we asked if there was a faster way they said that we could go to the restaurant to get it opened, but they wouldn't do it either. The check-in process is extremely slow here, I don't think it has ever taken more than a minute to check in at a hotel, but this process took about 5 and the people kept asking the exact same questions. It's in a good location and the staff are friendly, but that's about it.

Cons: No coffee maker, no bottled water, no cable tv. Why, Monte Carlo, can't you just put a coffee maker in every room...... 

Pros: Convenient location on the strip, free tram to bellagio (or so my tour guide said... I didn't take the tram myself), clean room

I've been before and just don't recall it being so yuck.  I had booked the Monte Carlo because after some web searching my son thought it had the best pool inclusive of waves and a lazy river.  Photo shop apparently does a lot more than cover pimples, sun damage, and cellulite.  The rooms are aged and currently neighbors with a major construction project that goes on round the clock.  After pulling an all nighter because of the never ending sounds of bulldozers, not the kind of sleepless night I'm used to in sin city, I asked to change my room and was thrown into a customer service nightmare.  I awoke with a different room, a broken TV, and a plumbing issue.

Not a reason in the world for this girl to ever go back.

Worst casino I have stayed in to date! Line wasn't too long for check in but when I get to my room they put me in a room someone was already in, luckily no one was in there so I walked back down and ask for another room, the second room I was given was almost ok just had the pillows on the floor but I just decided to stay, hallways are very dark and dirty, carpet coming up almost every other step making my wife trip and fall. After resort fee and basic room charge it came out to about 160 not including the $26 I had to pay a valet cuz they failed to mention a 13 per day fee when leaving my car. I could have taken my almost 200 to somewhere nicer, never again will I stay at this casino.

This was our first time at the Monte Carlo.  1st, the guest service staff were fantastic.  Extremely helpful.  We were charged a resort fee, but there was no resort because of construction. The rooms were clean but outdated. The casino lacked machines.

3.5 stars! We have been staying here for quite a few years and always have great service and nice clean rooms! With business being slow, we are offered comps here and just got back from a recent stay! Stayed in a great room and were treated and comped VERY well. Not over the top fancy or anything, just more old school vegas! Go stay here if you do NOT want all the traffic from the visitors....

For a "cheaper" hotel the Monte Carlo is very nice.
I stay here because I get discounted room rates for my play, and I am very pleased with the rooms.  Unless you are getting a suite, a hotel room in vegas is a hotel room.  The rooms here are very standard.

The main amenity I like is the food court.  In vegas, if you are not careful, you can quickly overspend on your budget.  Having a food court with cheap food options for breakfast or lunch is very nice to keep the trip within budget.

The pools are also nice - but different.  There is a lazy river and a wave pool.  The river is very nice to relax and float around in.

The casino floor is decent - not huge, but has enough games.

The poker room is small, but I enjoy the friendly dealers.  They are very nice and conversatons with them are enjoyable.  Because of this, I enjoy playing poker at MC.

Dated, horrible smell in the rooms. We had a complaint about the tub and the sewer smell and they didn't compensate us at all. Wouldn't even let us check out our last night there because we weren't happy with the service. Gross, old, bad customer service. For the price I could've stayed anywhere else on the strip. Never again.

We booked this through Hotels.com and received two buffet complimentary tickets (used a the Mirage Buffet.. separate review)... With resort fee it came to $80-ish minus the $54 buffet credits... it worked out to be $30-ish.. (we stay for two days and the buffet tickets were per stay, so my bill equated to $50-ish) still not bad for a Hotel right on the Strip. Compared Mandalay Bay ($180ish a night) it's not going to win but this hotel does have a lazy pool and wave pool for the kids as well.  The rooms were nice and the AC was quiet, beds were comfy.  The only thing I don't understand about this hotel is the Maid service.. upon entering the room, in the bath room, there were hair (of all types on the bathroom floors, I thought OK, so the maid didn't swipe the floors well enough.  Anywho next day, after the housekeeping, I notice more hair (different types).. I suspect our maid didn't rinse the mop well enough to clear.  Otherwise I would have rated this hotel higher...

BTW.. no WiFi avail

The outside look great but inside is dark, dingy, dirty (cigarette butt ash all over the machines) and the service for drinks is lacking (NIL).
I stayed here many years ago and it was not too bad then. 
I do hope this Vegas Institution can keep its doors open and I am holding off on giving it 1 star, maybe out of nostalgia. The Monte Carlo is iconic... just not a place I will step into again unless some drastic changes happen.

The Monte Carlo Resort & Casino- Las Vegas has bedbugs! Do not stay here anytime in the near future. 

I woke up with bedbugs crawling across my pillows and alerted the front. I had to leave for work and was told that they were going to do test and eventually came back positive. While I wrapped up a some last minute errands the hotel decided to violate my privacy rights by going thru my luggage without my permission when I wasn't even on site. On top of that they threw my luggage out without my permission! I didn't learn about this until 4 hours later. 

And after I got upset the front desk managers refused to speak with me and pushed me off onto security because "I was making a scene" then they got in my face and threatened to "throw me out of the hotel". Unbelievable that they made me out to be the ine in the wrong; especially after my company spent thousands there this weeks by housing 7 International Executives and Senior Sales Managers for 6 days. 

On top of all of this there are similar incidencs being reported on yelp as recent as 4 days ago. Luckily I have pictures and video evidence that I intend to share with trhe Nevada Dept. of Public Health & Human services, and formally file a complaint with the Attorney General's Office Paul Laxalt. 

If you decide to stay here sleep  tight....

Hands down my first choice hotel to stay at in Vegas.

Clean rooms, friendly staff, awesome pool area, centrally located, low price. What's not to like? 

I've stayed here both times I went to Vegas and was not disappointed. On my most recent visit I was able to check in and go to my room at 11:30AM. 

While the rooms are nice and clean, there is some noticeable wear and tear on the fixtures in the bathroom. Other than that I have no complaints about the room. 

There are plenty of options for meals and entertainment in all different price ranges. From the food court to a steakhouse and everything in between (even a cupcake shop!). 

The gym and spa are really nice. My friends and I got our money's worth of the resort fee ($12.95 per room per day) by using the gym 4 days on our visit and maybe taking more than our share of the complimentary water bottles (a bottle in the gift shop will set you back $3!). Use of the gym is included in the resort fee, but if you want to use the sauna\/steam room\/indoor jacuzzi it is $5 per day per person. Since we were running the Rock n Roll Las Vegas Half Marathon during our stay we decided to splurge on this stuff the day of the race and it was the perfect way to relax afterwards.

Pool area is awesome and even though on my most recent visit it was a bit chilly for it (50's-60's), my friends and I still went down one day and took advantage of the hot tub with intermittent dips in the regular pool. Sadly (although understandably because it was too cold for it) the wave pool and lazy river were closed.

Overall a great value, I think we paid something like $100\/night for 5 nights. Will definitely stay here if coming back to Vegas!

This hotel has a great location on the strip, the rooms seemed clean-ish, but was lacking in some of the little things that make some other Vegas hotels that little bit nicer, if not pricier.

The best thing about this hotel is the price and location.

The bedding seemed old, the blanket was scratchy, and I felt like the itchy blanket and bedspread had hidden herpes on it. Maybe it was just my imagination because I hate those hotel blankets. Much would have preferred those lovely duvets that some hotels have.

The bath products that were left for us looked like they had promise, but left my hair limp and difficult to comb out. The conditioner clearly did not condition. Yes, those little things make a difference for me.

Real shocker was how expensive the food court is - Starbucks was at least a dollar more than in Chicago, and I guess their Subway never heard that $5 footlooong song - the least expensive sub was a $6 - for a 6 inch!

The $10 resort fee pissed me off, even though I expected it from when I booked, because all you got was basically 2 small bottles of water and free local calls. Um, ok.

The casino wasn't too smoky, and had a few fun games, although the service was a bit lacking - you had to practically pounce on a waitress to get you a drink. We particularly liked the video blackjack games that you could bet 25 cents a hand. What - we're not big gamblers!

Overall, next time I'm in Vegas I think I would splurge that $20-$30 extra a night and stay somewhere a bit newer and nicer.
I think it's the best value in Vegas. Great pool, great friendly poker room if you want bigger games easy indoor walk to aria. Large selection of restaurants and room prices are very reasonable

The Monte Carlo treated me and my two girlfriends well, and I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a decent place to sleep and sun. The room was as basic as it gets and the subdued decor was a warm welcome after staying a previous night at the heavily themed Luxor. It's worth the price and location on the strip.
I stayed this past weekend (6\/8 to 6\/10) and noticed the construction nearby for the new City Center. NOT A BIG DEAL! We had a mountainside view and only heard construction once in the middle of the afternoon. The poolside was great, but the music and atmosphere was definitely geared towards a younger crowd. Pool bar $7 drink special was also great. I was pleased with my stay and will return as long as the price is right.

I don't know how I feel about the Monte Carlo. I stayed here for 3 nights over the weekend with my girlfriends for thier 21st birthday, and there were some definite goods and bads. 

Good:
-The location was great, right by city center, and close enough to walk to Caesars and all of the other big hotels.
-The food court. I spent so much time here trying to sober up. I love the options, even though I ate about 4 subway sandwiches.
-The pool area was soooo much fun!!! The lazy river and wave pool were always packed with drunk people. They had a lot of contests going on and djs playing and I won a dance contest doing the robot! Not great for children though.
-The rooms were pretty spacious, definitely enough room for the extra people that always end up sleeping on the floor. 

Okay, the bad:
-Our keys NEVER worked. When we checked in we got 3 keys, when we stumbled back to the room at night none of them worked. We even had to ask a security guard for help, and he couldn't open the room. We went down to the front desk and they apologized and gave us new keys and a $50 comp, but we went to the front desk about 2 more times to get new keys because the ones we had still didn't work. 
-The elevators took forever! And when you finally got on one, you ended up stopping at every floor. I think I rode down to the lobby with 10+ people each time.
-The room was broken...kinda. The first time I took a shower the tub wouldn't drain, so I was standing almost knee-deep in water. They sent up a plumber to look at it, but it was still gross. Also, when someone put a towel on the towel rack, it broke right off the wall. We called the front desk to tell them about it and make sure the room wasn't charged for it. 
-When we originally checked in, they said we didn't need a card to put on file for incidentals. I provided one, but they said it wouldn't be charged. I have never been to a hotel that didn't hold a deposit, so I thought it was weird. When we checked out, I was informed that $300 was charged to my card. The room wasn't even that much money. The guy at the front desk didn't have any idea why the card was charged, and we had to wait for a long time while he asked around and took it off.

All in all, I would stay there again, but it wouldn't be my first choice. Sorry about the 3-stars, but it wasn't bad, it wasn't great, it was average.

We have stayed here over the years many times. We travel as a big group usually, 5 families with five room's. We've always had great experiences here. One of the best things about this casino is how great the customer service at registration is. We tend to be difficult since we like adjoining rooms and to stay across from each other. Clayton is the attendant that help us at registration last time we stayed here and he was great. He was extremely patient with all our requests without being annoyed with us. He was wonderful and really set the tone for our whole vacation.

I stayed here with a group of people over a long weekend and everything was amazing when it came to the housekeeping and the people at the front desk and the people who accommodated me when booking the room was fabulous. When I got into the room I was upset because the pictures clearly are not what the room looks like. In the room the shampoo and conditioner had been used prior to whoever stayed before because it was half used and when I went to go to sleep there was stains on the sheets as well as the pillows which clearly would disturb anyone. Employees were amazing but when it came to cleanliness and the expectations of the room I was very disappointed.

Not luxurious like it was before when it was new but with that said the management at Monte Carlo have done a good job of keeping this place in good shape. The casino is clean and lively, sports book is solid, the wave pool and pool area in general was good, and the food court is solid. Our rooms were simple but clean. They need to add wifi and more electrical outlets and USB ports for the rooms. Overall we had a good experience.

I didn't love but I didn't hate this hotel. My recent stay here was my first and I truly wouldn't mind staying here again. The husband and I booked this hotel at a great price due to the fact that they are having some construction outside. We were helped by a friendly desk person who was also helpful and answered all our questions (mLife rewards, redeeming myVegas rewards, pubs\/lounges\/bars near by and even restaurant ). We were given our room key and helped within less than a few minutes. The lobby had a pretty Christmas tree already set up, a bar and a few benches to sit at. Our room was in the 17th floor with the view of a a few of the hotels on the strip. The room is indeed in HIGH need of a remodel. The tv is very outdated, there is a few pieces of the wall paper coming out, the tub was cracked, the lighting is sooo bad and the colors are pretty dull. The room itself isn't very welcoming but for the price we paid, we didn't mind. We didn't have any noise complaints, the bed was ok in comfort and the water in the shower was hot and steamy. I did not like though that the reception in our room was terrible! I later found out that there is only wifi in the first two floors, boooo!!! Better reception would make this place a lot better. I was also sad that the ice machine in our floor was broken, therefore we had to go one floor up to get ice.. 

I loved the location of this hotel and casino! It is so close to the tram and near the middle of the strip. Being that it was a rainy weekend, I had no trouble getting from Monte Carlo, Aria, Vdara and even the Cosmopolitan without getting too wet just by taking the tram and walking through the casinos. Excalibur and Luxor are across the street and Monte Carlo is walking distance from Coca Cola Factory and M and M World... very very convenient in my opinion. 

Monte Carlo has a decent size gambling casino downstairs with plenty of roulette tables, poker tables and slot machines to test your luck in. They have a Starbucks as well, The Brand Steakhouse, a Buffet and The Pub. If you want to catch a show, Monte Carlo currently has the Blue Man group.

For $69\/night, I can't complain.  The room was a decent size, the bathroom was huge, and it's at an excellent location on the strip.  When we checked in, I attempted the sandwich trick by sticking a $20 between a credit card and ID in an attempt to get an upgrade.  The guy was honest and checked all the suites but they were unavailable for 3 consecutive nights but gave us back our money and put us on a higher floor with a view of the strip which was pretty nice.  

Unfortunately, November is too cold so the pool was pretty dead but my GF and I did check it out.  There are like 3-4 different pools including a lazy river and a wave pool but too bad the hot tub was broken.  In addition, there's a very useful store downstairs across from the lobby to buy your snacks and alcohol.  There's also a small food court with McDs and Sbarro that's open late so you can grab a bite after partying before heading back to your room.  And lastly, there's a tram that takes you from to the City Center and into Bellagio which is pretty convenient.  Overall, great stay at an excellent price.  I would definitely stay here again.

Average category hotel in terms of services. Like once we reach hotel after a long journey what we generally expect, to check in hotel room as early as possible. But here you can't expect that . you will find a long queue waiting to check in. Goshhhhhh. Terribly long. Same case while you check out from hotel. One more thing the room was OK type. So over all it is an average type hotel thanks.

Let me first say that I normally do not stay on the strip or anywhere near here. I'm a Golden Nugget type of person. The younger crowd that hang out in these strip casinos are full of douchey people that all think they are high rollers when in fact they are all spending their paychecks and savings accounts trying to fit in paying for over priced bottles of wine and terrible service. So this particular trip we were looking for somewhere that had a cool pool because we had the kids with us. Note: kids don't belong in Vegas it's boring for them here. We were just passing thru coming home from vacation. So looking at who had cool pools we would of normally stayed at the MGM. But we wanted to try somewhere new. DUM DUM DUUM! This place is over crowded and over priced. Their rooms are terrible! I literally called the front desk because I said I wanted 2 queens but the queen are more like twin beds. They are SMALL! Very small for a queens. And I have been in better rooms at the Plaza for less than half the price. Bathroom was plain and small. The rooms are very small as well. Just to put it plainly, I WAS NOT IMPRESSED AT ALL! You here about these places on the strip. Yes, the casino was nice. But the other place like the rooms and the pool were just not up to par at all for the price. Big thumbs down for the price. Be happy you got 2 stars. Will never stay here again I don't think.

Nice hotel with excellent amenities. Highly recommended.  They have a food court with a McDonald's, subway that is open 24 hours, Sbarro, a Mexican restaurant and more. Brand steakhouse turns into a club lounge at night and it's pretty cool.  They have a nice pool area with several pools and a lazy river, with DJ and bars out there, and plenty of lounge chairs.  It is convenient to the Strip and the Tram.

Poor service and you're nickle-and-dimed. I checked in on a Sunday, at 11:30 a.m., after waiting in line for about 15 minutes. The clerk took my information and credit card and said that my room was available, but she would not tell me the room number, unless I paid $20 extra, for getting the room before 3 p.m. I said I would not pay, so she gave me the keys, without telling me the room number and said that I would get a phone call between 3 and 5:30. Again, I could avoid the delay for the room that was already ready, if I forked over another $20. I told her I wouldn't play the hotel's nickle and dime game and gave her my cell number. At 1:30, I received a call that I could go to my room. (So the $20 would have paid for 2 hrs.) I asked if my suitcase, that I left at he bell desk, could be brought to my room. She said, "no." I would have to go to the bell desk, myself. I left the poker game I was in and went to the bell desk. As I was waiting in another line, I overheard a bellman telling another patron that, when his room was ready, he could call a number on the receipt from the bell desk, and the baggage would be brought to his room. What was that? Was the hotel just hitting me up for a couple more bucks for a tip? The room was mediocre, at best. The mattress was like a cheap motel bed. The linens were low end. The bathroom amenities (soap, lotion, etc.) were horribly low quality. (When I applied some of the lotion, I needed to take a shower to get it off.) The drinks, in the casino, are tiny and low-end. The wifi is slower than I have ever experienced. There is no check-out, on the television. This is a low class motel, in a high rent district.

came to vegas on a last minute trip to see a concert at caeser's palace and booked my hotel through bookit.com and the monto carlo was one of the cheaper ones on the strip. upon entering the hotel room looked nice and beds were all made up and looked soft and the view was pretty nice, but that about stops the good things. 

the blankets might have been nice and soft, but the pillows were way too high for me. felt like i was sleeping on 3 pillows. on the last night i notice there was a stain on my blanket, had no idea what it was. my mom said it was lipstick, but i'm pretty sure it wasn't. the towels had this weird smell to it... and one of towels was still dirty. and the water pressure is ridiculous! i thought i was being sprayed by a firefighter hose. even though they came in everyday to clean the room there was always hair left on the bathroom floor. 

i guess you get what you paid for. if you really are just looking for a place to sleep and don't care how the room is, then i say go for the monto carlo. but i can say for sure i won't be booking a room here the next time i come back to vegas.

Not at all impressed,was playing cards on table,hot hot outside and expecting like cold water from service,half an hour passed n thirsty,still waiting for water and lastly I asked dealer can I have water or any drinks n she looked at me asked how long u playing ??? Been to many many casino,never experienced such bad service n unhappy dealers ! Never coming to empty Monte Carlo

I am a returning guest who had the opportunity to stay in their newly renovated suite.  They did a great job on their renovations.  I like Monte Carlo because of it's central location on the strip and because they are part of the Mlife rewards which we love.  Their new suite includes new carpet, two large flat screens, two seating areas as well as a walk in closet. The bathroom is completely new with a very spacious shower, new counter and sink as well as a new toilet.  The artwork gives it a feel of home away from home.  There are two full length mirrors.  One in the walk in closet and the other in the hallway.  Please see video and photos.  I highly recommend this room.

The buffet was horrible for the price. Pay tge exta $10 and go to the Belagio or similar hotel.  Food was salty, low quality, and server s weren't very nice. Seating area is very uncomfortable.  Last thing I left gratuity but you get your own drinks.  If your looking for a quick bite to eat then this is the place for you.  There was no line.  Now I see why.

I feel like I need to give an updated review as it has changed and is going through some heavy renovation.  We stayed here and were given an upgraded room in one of their newly renovated floors.  Whoa, interesting upgrades!

The bathroom is spacious.  No longer beige and ugly with their out-dated shower\/tubs and towels smelling of burnt popcorn, now they have a large roomy shower with red tiling.  The sinks are modern but I didn't like them.  The water pooled and cleaning them must suck for housekeeping.  The beds were soft but pretty low on the ground.  There's no conventional desk for your laptop but a long couch by the window with a standing table serves to remedy this problem.  Other than that, those are all your major furniture bits.  The WiFi is TERRIBLE! In this day and age, that's unacceptable.  I was pretty much using data in my room.  Um, no, I don't want that.  Give your guest a password safe network like all the other hotels.

There are no dining options besides their food court in the hotel at the moment due to construction but they're a short walk from The Park and is still accessible to Aria.  These new renovations have potential though.  I can't wait to see how this place ends up looking now that the T-Mobile Arena is next door and they house the Park Theater.

They have some low table minimums so that's always a plus if you don't want to break the bank. Cocktail waitresses are always walking around.

Monte Carlo is still a great central location on The Strip.  Everything is within walking distance and if you're too lazy to walk, take the tram!

Our first stay here and it will be our last. We were given an incorrect room at check in, we went back down and had it corrected with no form of apology. The girl at the desk actually seemed upset that I wanted the room I had booked. 

The carpets are disgusting, the bathroom fixtures are junk, etc etc

Seemed very glamorous from the outside whenever I saw pictures and passed by. We stayed there for 4 days recently and I have to say that it was pretty funny having a McD's in the lobby. =) The only issue I had was the fact that my floor's vending machine was ALWAYS out of bottled water!!! I had to travel to the next floor up each and every time. I called the Concierge about this and they apologized and said they would fix it but to no avail. You'd think that in HOT Vegas, H2O would be imperative on their service list??? *sigh*

Stayed at the Monte Carlo for a conference otherwise probably wouldn't even have given the somewhat negative reviews.
The public areas of the hotel-casino are quite nice as is the spa\/exercise room. There is a variety of decent dinning options, including a food court that has a McDonald's, Subway, a fresh Mex and pizza place. 
I stayed on a non-smoking floor (23), which was quiet. The room itself was in need of updating. The carpet was clean but worn and the furniture was both beat up and dated (the drawn on the desk kept sliding open for no reason and I finally had to wedge a piece of paper in it to keep it shut. 
The bed and pillows were comfortable and the bedding was adequate but nothing fancy. The bath was adequate with tile floor and a good shower (though some might find the flow pressure a bit high). 
Overall, the room reminded me of a basic Comfort Inn or Best Western.
The location is good and there is a CVS next door, which is convenient for snacks and any essentials.
MGM bills the Monte Carlo as the budget\/entry level alternative to the Aria at the City Center, which is right next door. That's an accurate description.

Really not worth it only best part was good bed i mean it was horrible flush not wrk nor where the towels clean the carpet in hallway was older thn my apt i paid more to get better room and this was better room i can imagine how would be the other rooms nyhow cheap Mlife hotel for a night you can try other mgm brands like mandlay bay which is excellent and mgm grand which is good the best i like is bellagio and ventian from my stays

I was honestly hesitant to stay here because of the many bad reviews on here but I just came back from my first time in Vegas and we stayed at the monte carlo and I had an awesome experience don't be fooled by the reviews. It was a nice hotel, with many things inside to explore and the fact that there is 2 starbucks in it was a huge bonus for me. Also the location was really good also. Overall my stay we great

Was a one star review. In trying to resolve my issue with the front desk over phone, I wasn't treated very well, but when I went down stairs in person and asked for a manager, all was explained and resolved. Blake, the manager at the time was spot on. He and the people at check-in deserve recognition.  I only give four stars because I had to be so insistent on getting my issue resolved. There are definitely still some kinks, but once Blake got involved, all was well.

Not sure where to start... the number of missed steps are vast. The Monte Carlo has the audacity to charge a resort fee as they have nothing that resembles a resort. They do not have a spa, a pool or any food.  Plus they only have a 1\/3 of a casino open and an inadequate number of front desk staff to manage the guest check in and phones...The hotel is obviously under renovation. One would think they need to explain to a potential guest before they book the resort there will be absolutely nothing on the property that resembles a resort.  

How can you charge a resort fee and feel like you are not cheating the guests? Unbelievable, really!  

First, this resort is a real honest to goodness FOOD DESERT!  When I called downstairs to inquire about food I was greeted with an answer of, "we just don't have anything right now but you could go to another property for food!" Are you kidding me I am not able to eat at the resort I am staying at, really?  Seems like a relatively minor request consider this is Las Vegas and all...this resort is not the Travel Lodge.  I realize as I was wasting away from food deprivation that this would be the best place for someone post bariatric surgery...zero temptations.  I do not think that is the demographic you are marketing to or it was not clear when I booked.  

Second, on the first full day I was here I returned to my room after a full day away to a pair of men's shoes and socks in my room.  I called downstairs to inquire who was in my room and was greeted with a response of, "it probably was the housekeeping staff who left the shoes and socks there because they could have been found in another room and the cart was full."  Really that is your answer?  They were tucked nicely at the end of the platform bed in plain sight.  Riddle me this, why would the housekeeping staff bring shoes and socks into my room and neatly place the at the foot of my bed? This does not even seem plausible, right?  The front desk manager said they would check the door entrance swipes to see who entered the room.  So they called me back to tell me that only housekeeping entered my room...when asked they were unwilling to share the proof, so who really knows...

And the trifecta...Here is the absolute worst inexcusable thing about the entire stay the staff are rude at best!  Unapologetic, arrogant, non-customer centric savages, at least the ones that I encountered from check in to check out!  One would think they would be apologizing or at least sympathizing with with the guests but nope, quite to the contrary!  

Shame on you MGM Resorts...I thought better of you!!!  You have so much work to do to convert this property from a -1 Star resort to a 5 Star resort that you are attempting to become!  Changing a name will not change the customer service and customer experience!  

I welcome you to contact me because I will be happy to share names with you if you are interested  in learning from the abysmal visit. 

I am very sad!  I feel like I was cheated out a vacation that I was promised by the Monte Carlo...I am not able to take too many vacations but when I do I expect certain things...these things were just not at the Monte Carlo!

Everyone is so friendly with the exception of the gentleman that checked us in he was quite short and rude when checking us in....got to room tv unplugged alarm clock unplugged room had a terrible odor to it possibly could be carpet with big huge stains all over it...called and complained that nothing was working and the room stunk they offered to send up housekeeping 

As for the reason that it's not a 1 star is everyone else was so friendly from table games to concierge desk to waitresses (although my wife played slots and nobody came by for drinks maybe because they don't tip?) eh think next time I will splurge and stay at Aria everyone rants and raves about them lesson learned

So, it was super inexpensive which means I can handle that the rooms are run down and it's being renovated. However, I can't handle a hotel not picking up trash or cleaning the room properly. I checked in and found a q-tip on the floor (pic attached). I was there for two nights and the entire time there was a bag full of half eaten food in the hallway which I passed by each day and night (pic also attached). In retrospect, the rooms are so trashed and dirty that I would not stay at this place again. Find another cheap option.

This is where we stay when we go to Vegas on the cheap.  The rooms are decent but definitely not sound proof...ask for a room that is not connected to the room next door.  We had a family next door to us and we probably could have contributed to their conversations.

There is not anything real special about the Monte Carlo, except for the location.  But I had to give the MC three stars because it is the only casino in Vegas where I have actually won decent money.  Everywhere else robs me blind.

I have no idea why this place isn't rated higher. I've stayed at the Rio, Treasure Island (first guest in a refurbished room a few years ago) and honestly, I love Monte Carlo. First and foremost, when it comes to social media, Monte Carlo is all over it. They're quick to respond to questions on Twitter, and are super helpful with recommendations. The staff at the resort itself is the same. We went to Vegas to do pool time and boozing. So our gambling consisted of $20 at the video poker machines at Ignite Bar (by Minus 5) and that included all we could drink. Bet 25 cents a hand, and you can really get your money's worth. And I won! Who actually wins on video poker? 

The pool is awesome. Lazy river, wave pool, huge hot tub and a regular pool give you plenty of options. We were there April 14-17 and we were never crowded when we were outside. 

Breakfast buffet is affordable and $4 extra gets you unlimited Mimosas. Seriously? Yes. And there are crab legs on the breakfast buffet. Amazing. 

Rooms were clean, had what we needed (because seriously, who spends a lot of time in their room in Vegas?), and when we needed more towels or whatever, they were quick to send those up. 

The Pub... Diablos... The watering holes at the Monte Carlo do not disappoint. Loved the chili garlic wings and sliders (AND HELLO BEER SELECTION) at the Pub, and Diablos is an awesome venue for some night time cocktails. 

Huge fan of the Monte Carlo. It's not a 5-star hotel, but they aren't claiming to be. Unpretentious Luxury is their thing, and it's perfect for me. I'll stay at the Monte Carlo again, for sure.

In my opinion one of the better budget options on the strip.  My go to place to stay when my favorites are a bit too pricey.  Stayed here several times including two stays during Memorial Day weekend.

Room:
The rooms are usually clean, but outdated.  There can be some cleanliness issues as others have mentioned but for the most part I did not ever feel disgusted.  My only complaint would be the restroom, specifically the shower.  The water pressure is terrible and the temperature does not get boiling hot as I like.  This is a big drawback for me as I enjoy taking several showers a day after dealing with the dessert heat, and I like my showers hot!  So if these are your pet peeves, hope you get lucky with a decent shower.

Location:
Definitely a positive, and one of the reasons I would choose to stay at the Monte Carlo over some of your other cheaper options.  There is a free tram that connects you to the Aria\/City Center and Bellagio.  We used the tram to get us to the Bellagio and took a short walk through the resort to connect to Caesar's and also to Planet Hollywood across the street.  Trams take no more than 15 minutes to arrive.  You can also walk into the Aria directly through the same walkway that takes you to the tram.  

Pool:
The pool is also definitely a positive, and would be a factor in why I would choose to stay here.  There are 3 pools, a regular pool, a small lazy river, and a wave pool as well as a beach volleyball court!  The pool area itself is small and can be difficult to find a few chairs, usually we were able to find some next to the volleyball courts.  You can check out a volleyball from the desk with an I.D., however pay attention to the ball as we were constantly hitting it over the wall into the street, and had to go chase it down using the exit doors.
