But other than that, I loved it all.

I stayed at the Monte Carlo over New Years and was very impressed. The check-in was fast and the staff was very friendly. While the room was not over the top, it was spacious and most importantly, very clean. 

The Monte Carlo is in a prime location, affordable, and is more low-key compared to other hotels on the strip. I will definitely be staying here again!

Location is prime if you want to be near the T-mobile arena, MGM or Aria. Other than the convenient location, this hotel\/casino is pretty old, run down and filled with cigarette smoke. The rooms are decent in size but could definitely use an update in decorations, the bathroom and the beds, which felt so sunken in. Carpets looked pretty dirty with stains and the walls are PAPER THIN. You could hear your neighbors music or them going at it (beds so old they squeak). The hotel is going under a renovation right now so the pool is closed. They offer you access however to the pools at Mandalay Bay, MGM and Aria, but seriously, who is going to want to walk outside the hotel for that? Overall, its price is ok for location and if you're on a budget. The amenities suck.

My gfs and I decided to stay at Monte Carlo for our girls weekend since it was the cheapest hotel the weekend we went that I would actually consider staying at.

MC is an older hotel\/casino and you tell with the ventilation.  Check in was a breeze since we arrived late.  The room itself is nothing special.  I did not like the fact that the bath tub had soap scum or that my bed sheets had stains on them.  Is it seriously that expensive to replaced a pair of sheets?  House keeping did not clean our room, which sucked because we needed new towels.

Pool area is on the small side.  City Centers buildings shadow the MC pool, which isn't good for a pool since one of the pools got no sunlight, but that might also be because of the time we went.  There is a lazy river, but to rent a tube its $9 and to buy one its $10.  Getting a tube would not really matter because the lazy river is packed with people just hanging out, no tube necessary.  The wave pool is fun and there is also a volleyball court.

Overall MC is not bad, but I had to dock a star for the lack of house keeping and stained sheets.

The acoustics all over the hotel are terrible, way too noisy. Even in the on site restaurants you can't get away from the roar of the casino. The rooms are nice and clean, but there is no microwave or refrigerator. For a place that never sleeps you'd think that you'd be able to get breakfast anytime, but that's not the case (although, when the omelet chef is working at the buffet, it's the best food in the place - you just have to be in line before 11am). For me, the gambling was just mediocre. I had a better time and better luck on the strip.
The hotel is in a great location, making it easy to travel to the Bellagio, Paris, etc. All of the staff are extremely friendly and helpful (shoutout to Shannon at the Bell Desk), and took care of every request that I made with no fuss or drama. Bottom line, it is a good value for the money, if you don't mind the noise and the lack of conveniences in your room.

Let me start off and say that the concierge at Monte Carlo was amazing! They are very service-oriented and made me feel like my patronage was appreciated.

The rooms were as expected- nice, without being overly luxurious or anything. However, the bathrooms were so subpar. What kind of a 4-star hotel bathroom only has 1 dim light? At least the light was over the sink, so I could apply my makeup properly. However, the tiny tub with the shower curtain was so dark, that I could barely see in the shower. The water pressure in the shower was also pretty terrible, and the water felt like a light drizzle. It also took forever and a day for the shower to get hot. I think it was 10minutes into my shower that I finally felt the water reach a comfortable temperature. I had it on the hottest possible, and didn't need to turn it down at all during my 20 minute shower. 

Wifi is only complimentary in the lobby and public areas, and guests have to pay for wifi in their rooms. 

The pool was awesome, and we really enjoyed the lazy river (inner tube rentals at a fee). We didn't get to the wave pool, but everyone seemed to really enjoy that as well. We managed to squeeze into the jacuzzi with about 8 other people. 

The concierge was very helpful in booking Blue Man Group tickets for us a few hours before the show. We got discounts on seats towards the front of the theater, thanks to our m-life membership. 

The checkout process was very efficient and simple, thanks to their check out computer kiosks. And they were more than happy to hold our bags for us until our flight in the evening. 

I'm not exactly sure if I would stay in the Monte Carlo again because of the bathrooms. Although the rest of our experience there was amazing, a dark bathroom with measly tepid water is a huge bummer.

I don't know what the rooms are like, but the pool! The pool is amazing! You have a lazy river that is always good, kid pee and all. You have a huge wave pool. Now that's amazing! It's vegas, this is what I like to do when I go. I wish I could go way more often. I would recommend this pool. Casino? I have no idea.

I think the Monte Carlo is an extremely fun and fabulous hotel if you're in your 20's and with a bunch of girl friends.  We stayed here last year when we were in Vegas for our friend's bachelorette party.  We didn't do any bachelorette things at the Monte Carlo but it was still a fun place for the 3 of us to stay and hang out separately from all the others.  

The pool is fantastic!  There are several different parts to the pool and even a wave pool!  Awesome :)  It attracts a nice crowd - a mix of young and old alike and families too, but still pretty hip and happening.  And it's not annoyingly crowded or anything. 

I recommend this place highly!

I got a really great deal on this hotel considering I was visiting Las Vegas during Thanksgiving week.  So once my husband and I had checked in, we dropped our bags off to our room and were on our way.  The best thing about this hotel is its proximity to everything.  It's in a great location, you can take a tram to the Bellagio and walk the other part of the strip, and the rooms don't take a thousand years to walk to after a long day.  

We didn't return until late that evening.  After a day of travel and shopping, all I was looking forward to was a nice hot shower and getting  a good night's sleep.  However, I started noticing little things that began to bother me.  First, the shower drain was clogged and the carpet looked as if it hadn't been vacuumed thoroughly.  Then, the drinking glass was dirty.  Now, I was willing to overlook the glass, and I figured I'd let housekeeping know in the morning about the shower, but then when I sat on the bed, I started to form a rash on my wrists.  Finally, when I pulled the covers back from the bed, I noticed strands of hair on the bed. 

My husband called the front desk and they immediately switched our rooms.  The next room was on a higher floor and A LOT cleaner than the previous room.  The biggest hassel was moving all our luggage and shopping bags at 1 am.  

I guess sometimes it's hit or miss.

I was really looking forward to my vacation, here at the Monte Carlo. I feel as though the pictures of the rooms are misleading. The carpet was extremely dirty, we had a reservation for three but never went a day without calling for three sets of towels, the tub had too much mold and the worse part, we had to kill a roach crawling in our room. Needless to say, I am very disappointed and will never stay again.

This was my first trip to Vegas, and I was pretty happy staying at the Monte Carlo. Great location on the strip, right in the middle of everything. It's also incredibly convenient that the free tram is nearby. 

The Monte Carlo is much less fancy spancy than many other resorts, but it averaged out to under $80 per night over Thanksgiving weekend. The price is right, and we barely spent any time in the hotel room anyway. Just for sleeping and showering. Spending less on hotel means more money for dining and entertainment!

I don't have any complaints about cleanliness of our hotel room, but the decor was quite outdated. It was pretty difficult to turn the shower faucet. Some of the furniture was pretty worn out too. Internet is included in the resort free, but there is no wifi available (only wired internet) above the second floor. 

There's some construction going on at Monte Carlo and New York New York. Looks like both places will be getting some upgrades soon.

The hotel rooms had everything you need, the bed looked funny, but it served its purpose.  There were many great places to eat, gamble and explore inside the hotel.  This place serves as a great place to start a walking tour of the strip ending past the Circus Circus.
If you come back to the hotel, there is plenty of wild happenings.

My fiance and I stayed at the Monte Carlo this weekend. After looking at some of the negative reviews I was thinking we would have to change hotels, but when we arrived we found the staff to be friendly and helpful, the entire hotel and room to be spotless, and our overall experience was great! Pool party was kinda loud during the day but who is in their room during the day? The spa was great (too expensive though, I've never paid so much for a facial). Granted the hotel is older and the floors and fixtures are gold finish like it's 1975 but the chipped floors were shined beyond belief and the place was well maintained. The only negative we had was a weird shower head, it kind of sprayed at you like it was the police and you were a protester - a little too forceful and sort of all over the place.

Perfectly adequate. 

I stayed in the Monte Carlo following a canceled flight (hurricane Irene) for 6 (yes, 6) nights. 

Monte Carlo is not an upscale Las Vegas resort. There, that's out of the way. If you want upscale, go to the Bellagio or Wynn or Encore or any of number of other places. 

What Monte Carlo offers is: 
1) Prime location. If you are planning on exploring the Las Vegas Strip, Monte Carlo make a great home base. It is centrally located and easily accessible. 
2) Totally average accommodations. The hallways may be crappy and old, but the guest rooms are perfectly average. They are no better or worse than a typical Holiday Inn (pre-renovation). Sure, they could use updating, but the beds are acceptable, the rooms are clean and you feel safe while you are there. For under $50 (or so) a night, you will not find a better deal ON the strip. 
3) A nice gaming atmosphere. The tables (blackjack, roulette) always seem inviting and friendly, they have some of the friendliest dealers and in general it is a nice place to gamble. 

The pool and lazy river are decent (nothing spectacular) and the walkway\/access to the CityCenter Tram is a huge plus (it is very easy to get out and explore).

Monte Carlo is not fancy. Accept that and you will have a good time. If you cannot accept that, don't stay there (there are tons of fancy places to stay). 

In general, Monte Carlo attracts a younger crowd (or so it seemed to me in my 6 days there and in my previous visits).

The Monte Carlo is very 'generic' as far as hotels go on the Las Vegas Strip. This definitely does not make the hotel bad, but you can find a much more vibrant and exciting atmosphere at any of the other casino's around it. The place is huge, and the rooms are fairly large and clean, and the views are awesome. If you're looking for something nice and a little more pedestrian, then the Monte Carlo would suit you just fine. One big plus is it's location near Aria, the MGM Grand, New York New York, and the Bellagio.

This is second time staying at the Monte Carlo and have enjoyed it both times. We had a high floor strip view room that overlooked the south end of the strip by the MGM. It was a nice room, just not worth the $$ for the view. I was hoping for a better view of the Strip for what I paid. 

We fell in love with the beds and pillows - so comfy! The bathroom was clean; however, the drains in the bathtub and sink were very slow. No bueno. I would like to see the Monte Carlo catch up to their competitors by adding a microwave & fridge to the room as well as replacing the wired Internet access with Wi-Fi. I know people with tablets would be oh so very appreciative. The new flat screen TV's are really nice - too bad they give you crappy remote controls to use it. You'd think you'd get a nice remote to accompany a sweet TV. No such luck here. 

The pool and jacuzzi are nice, clean and well staffed, with towels at each lounge chair so you already have one waiting for you. Of course, you can get more if needed. The pool is heated as well. We didn't get into the other areas of the pool but from what we saw, they were nice. 

Valet parking was included - muy bueno - and the service was top notch. The same thing goes for the bell desk & security services. I left my bathing suit (brand new and super nice!) in the room and they were able to retrieve it for me. Talk about service! 

Check in was easy but check out was a bit hairy. They don't deliver a print out of your bill to your room, which I expected from the last time I was there. When I called, I was told it was because they have over 3,000 rooms. Translation = they cut staff. I was instructed to view my bill via the TV and if acceptable, I can check out that way. I followed the instructions but man, who would've thought something so easy would present so many challenges. First off, my remote decided it didn't want to work unless I tried 30 times, which I had to do until I got some results. I coudn't view my bill in it's entirety, only a pending charge, so I had to call the front desk back to find out what that was for. Okay, check. I then went back to the TV to try and check out and after hitting the same buttons on my remote like 10 times, I finally got the "you've successfully checked out" message on the TV. WTH Monte Carlo? 

MC does need to step their game up, especially for what they charge. Overall, though, despite the check out mess, we enjoyed the stay. I'd stay again although going forward, I plan on keeping my money in downtown Vegas.

This hotel is a nice little gem in the crown of the city center\/aria\/ bellagio strip area. The room was fairly clean and served as a good place to relax after the strip. The staff onsite were nice and professional. The housekeeping was just so\/so. They ran out of towels one day and made us keep our towels that were dirty. That was disappointing for a hotel this size. The food was decent on the property but I bit pricey for Denny's quality buffet and cafe. The food court was good for quick eats but it was not gourmet just food. I really enjoyed the bell staff, virtual black jack, the sports book, the tram to the bellagio and the nice casino drink servers. I would come back if the price was right.

I have to say out of all the hotels in Vegas this is the most decent one. Everything isn't overly fabulous, which is nice every once in awhile, and it just is what it is.
The Monte Carlo doesn't try to be anything its not, and its perfect just the way it is. 
The rooms are extremely decent. The food is extremely decent.
If you're going here for a turn around, or even just for a weekend trip, this is a good place to stay.
Not bad and not extremely good. But somewhere in the middle.
It's a good pick, and I would recommend it, it's just not my absolute favorite.

I really enjoyed my stay here. I was given a beautiful view of the mountains on a higher floor than I was reserved for. Quiet, comfortable and clean. 

The check in line moves quickly, the parking lot was well designed. 

However, avoid the Sabarro... All 3 of my girls and I woke up with fevers after a late nigh pizza run.

Eh. 

Booked a flight\/ hotel deal through Expedia and it all comes down to this: you get what you pay for. I was expecting a little more from the Monte Carlo. Between complete trash and complete class, this place is just plain mediocre. Not horrible, not great. The staff was helpful enough. The decor is kind of plain. The phone in our room was broken, so it was a hassle just to order a cork screw. 

The biggest let down of them all was the pool. They stop serving alcohol at 6 and it closes at 7. AND you can't walk around in the pool with your drink. I thought we were in Vegas! The day we did spend at the pool wasn't all that bad, but it WAAAS their 4th of July BBQ, so they may have "pulled out the stops". Who knows. 

Overall, for the price and the fact that not much time is actual spent in the room, I'd stay here again. Plus, it's in a central spot on the strip (which is the main reason we picked this place).

Stayed here for 3 nights for a very cheap rate of about $260? right after christmas! This was the MC Winter Wonderland Package, which included 2 complimentary buffets, free play money, and coupons to restaurants in the hotel!  Too bad, we never tried out MC's buffet for free!  I We got the 31st floor room which was an awesome view of the mountains and sun rising and freeway full of cars!  I wanted the strip view but the bellman was right.. The new city buildings under construction are hiding Monte Carlo's view of the strip so it was better that we got the other view of Vegas!  The 32nd floor was closed for renovations.. I think the whole hotel is under renovations in general.. the lobby of each floor is pretty empty with like 2 chairs and carpet.. nothing too special or fancy.. But hotels are hotels right... I was barely in my room the whole entire trip anyways! Beds, pillows, and blankets were definitely comfortable for my taste after a long day and night of walking\/gambling around.  Valet is complimentary for guests. There is a parking lot across the street for short term parking which is hard to find though.. It is packed! The outside of the hotel has a nice theme\/decor to it which i absolutely love.. but the inside just really doesn't match it at all.. I guess they got lazy!

Casino: Nothing too fancy..no decor really.. just some casual place to gamble downstairs if your feet can't make it anywhere else!

I don't mind staying here again if i were tight on money! :)

I'll keep this short and sweet. This is a fine hotel.  The staff are friendly and courteous.  The housekeeping staff kept our room clean for the 6 nights we stayed.  They were lovely in accommodating my need for a small refrigerator for the room (rooms do not come with fridges - this is standard in Las Vegas, apparently.)  There was a food court with lots of choices if you want a small bite or quick breakfast - we opted for McDonalds every morning but the first, when we found out how expensive the Starbucks was.  Checkin and checkout were easy and fast.  The parking valets were SUPER - we always had our car within 5 minutes (mostly less).  It's not GLITZY or GLAMOROUS - it's modern, neat and clean.  Listen: you're in Vegas.  You're gambling, drinking or whatever.  You need a clean bed and a clean shower in a clean bathroom.  All of those needs were met.  WELL WORTH IT.

Monte Carlo pleasantly surprised me! The rate I paid for a Sunday-through-Tuesday visit was well below $100\/night, which initially made me question how good this hotel could be. But upon arrival, all my doubts were alleviated. We ended up arriving to the property a bit early (2+ hours before check-in). We waited in line at the front desk for less than 10 minutes. They promptly checked us is and told us our room was ready! That was music to my ears, considering I was running on fumes -- as one often does in Vegas. 

The interior of the hotel is luxurious, with marble floors throughout and a nice soft goods update. Our king bed deluxe room was spacious, had a flat screen TV and came with internet (not WiFi though). The bed was my favorite part! Soft, comfy, with plenty of pillows and blankets, which let you create the sleeping environment you want. 

Downsides: lighting is not enough, especially in the bathroom; you better hope the people staying next door to you are considerate because you can hear almost everything going on in their room; the marble tiles in the bathroom and hallway can be very slippery, so watch out! 

If I need a quick getaway to my second-favorite city, I'd definitely consider staying at the Monte Carlo again!

cheap and out dated . that said the room smelled like bug spray and just cause we checked in early they charged us $ and downgraded our room  over looking air conditioning units. deff one of the worse rooms I've stayed in.

we booked the monte carlo for my cousins stag and unfortunately were not impressed. the first room we stayed in the bathtub didnt even drain so when we showered it was a pool of water. when we called and complained they changed our room although they failed to mention that we had to grab our items in one shot because our keys were deactivated. with only 2 hands we of course didnt grab everything.. once again we had to call management which consisted of transferring from person to person.. we got ONLY a 50$ credit after all the headache we experienced. to top it off the rooms dont have a mini fridge. what hotel doesnt have one of those nowadays? avoid monte carlo. its dated and disgusting.

This was going to be the first visit for my husband since he was young. I was excited to show him the changes and all the new hotels and restaurants. 
We are also celebrating our retirements and birthday on this visit. Was going to enjoy and celebrate  our life!!!!
Unfortunately the room we received was a handicap  king room since that was under the package we had selected. That was OK since we selected it but light in bathroom  doesn't work and pool is being released constructed and unlucky us can see and hear construction through our window. Not sure if we're are going to stay the full time here. May try to check out and go elsewhere. 
Verify if construction is still in progress and make sure everything is operational as soon as you get onto room
Also, there is no WiFi  currently and no USB plugs available in room. Had to plug phone charger into low wall outlet since nothing available on tabletops , lamps or by TV Stand. 
Does not have microwave,  coffee maker for those interested. In bathroom,  towels are a little rough and 1 soap is left for both sink and shower. Good water pressure for being on the  20th floor.
Make sure you ask questions and revise hotel info before checking in. 
Unfortunately for us, we may need to check out and go elsewhere.   : (

Like Laughlin, but farther away. I've made some questionable choices in my life, but staying at the poorly maintained and dilapidated Monte Carlo, is akin to buying meth off old uncle Brewster in the parking lot behind the Dairy Queen. Thanks Monte Carlo, and MGM resorts, for being the Arco of hotels.

Room is loud, I can hear police go by and I am 20 stories up. The drone of the freeway has stopped me from sleep. None smoking room has the smell of smoke.

So much for a decent sleep. Sadly my flight is just a few hours out so a switch is pointless.
We got a spa suite, dirty carpets, holes in the wall, old dirty couches, and the room was completely out dated. Very disappointing.

THE POOL IS CLOSE!!! THE POOL IS CLOSED!!! The reason why we decided to do a staycation very disappointing. The check in line is ridiculous and the "mobile check in" is just as ridiculous. Reserved a room with 2 queen beds they gave a room with a just 1 king idiots what a stupid idea to do a staycation at the Monte Carlo
Motel 6 with lights.  Air is old and stale, no amenities and rude staff.  Few options on casino floor.

It's a 3.5 rating. It's not a party hotel so it has a more sedate feel to it and actually rather classy. The rooms could use a face lift but how often are you there? They're simple and clean and it's a bargain. I've stayed here for the bargain prices and I've always felt I've gotten my money's worth. The one warning I would give anyone though is to avoid Andre's French restaurant, it is a total tourist trap sleazy ripoff. The cigar bar above Andre's is nice though. Nice pool area too. Again, if you're looking for party central this ain't the place but it is the place for a nice quiet, fun getaway to Vegas.
Nice lazy river\pool, friendly staff, comfy beds, spacious rooms. Wish the windows opened a little more though... not the worst hotel on the strip and reasonable for the price

The last time I stayed here was during Comdex in 1999 or 2000.  I would be happy to review the room, but I am confident it was renovated since that time.  If not....ouch.

The casino is pretty old-school for how recently it was built.  I have played here a few times over the years when I was looking for somewhere to play other than the nearby MGM Grand where I was staying.  Nothing that memorable has happened here for me.

Lance Burton still has a show here.  I have never seen him, and have often wondered who does.

Recently, a mexican restaurant called Diablos opened on the Strip in front of the Monte Carlo.  I have not yet been there, but a local bartender friend of mine said the food was pretty good.

I never understood this property or who they are trying to capture as an audience.  I usually walk right by, but maybe that will change after City Center opens up next door.  Time will tell.
Great location but the hotel isn't that great, it's nice but I've been to a nicer one. I expected to pay less for the quality of the room and customer service.

This was the worse hotel I have ever stayed at and it was my honeymoon and I'm a local. Sit down for this. First off. When I booked this room it said NOTHING about the mass construction going on in the hotel for the next 2 years. They start the construction at 5:00AM. My room was vibrating. There was knocking and banging and drilling and loud talking and everything associated with construction was going on above our heads for the entire 4 day stay. I asked for an upgrade to suite and was told non were available. The best part about the room was the bed. It was very comfortable. It is very outdated. Old furniture. Dirty carpet. And the bathroom needed to be cleaned. The entire purpose of a honeymoon is to never leave the room til you the day you check out. My husband and I spent time out of the hotel because of the construction . Oh. And we almost got ran over by 2 construction men with a cart that were rude and told us that if we were walking to the side we never would have almost gotten hit. How freaking rude is that. This was a really really really bad honeymoon. I will be booking another honeymoon for me and my husband at another non MGM property hotel. And before I forget. They charge for parking. How in the hell are you going to charge for parking $10.00 per night when I'm staying at your hotel. No other hotel does that on the strip. Only MGM properties. Do yourself a favor. Pay the extra money and stay at a non MGM property hotel. You will thank me for it.

i would give this hotel a negative rating if i could. Only gave it a star just because of its great location on the strip. i booked this hotel because my aunts were staying here for the weekend as well. i should have spent extra $$ to stay at the wynn or somewhere else. if you're not staying at their spa suites then forget about this place. it's pretty worn down and outdated.

For the price of 32 a night it is a nice and Newley remodeled hotel room. The view from the 24th floor of the strip was beautiful. Getting from the garage to the room requires a little walking around due to construction but hopefully that will finish soon. The resort fee is just another stab in the side with a sharp stick. After talking to the Mlife counter and finding out that I could have gotten 10% off on my stay it kind of sucks, so please if you can call and see if there is anything you could get to discount your trip. I tried to call the front desk from the room cause it was absolutely packed but after 10 mins on hold I just gave up. The new room probably has close to the worst decor arrangement I have ever seen with how they place the walled picture frames. The bathroom was very nice. Overall clean in appearance and still smells new.

We try to stay somewhere different every time we go to Vegas and because this time, we only planned to stay one night on our way home from a California trip, I didn't want to spend a lot.

After searching Kayak, our three choices for decent lodging along with budget pricing was Monte Carlo, Rio or Paris Las Vegas. Both the Rio and Paris Las Vegas had mixed reviews while Monte Carlo seemed to be higher end. So we opted for a strip view room at the Monte Carlo.

Now first of all, don't be fooled by "strip view." Sure you can see some of the strip however the hotel is not located directly on the strip itself but set back quite a ways. So your view is limited.

I was also a bit disappointed with the dated room - its furnishings and decor. There was no refrigerator or even an honors bar (money making opportunity here) and the shower fixture was pretty gotty looking. I know I'm being a bit particular here but after staying at the Wynn last year, the Monte Carlo was disappointing. 

The hallway where our room was located (23rd floor) smelt like a skunk had been there. I'm not sure if it was actual skunk or someone smoking some skunk weed in one of the rooms. ;-)

Finally, waiting about 10 minutes for the elevator to finally stop on our floor during check-out time was all but ridiculous. I felt like I was waiting for a theme park ride without the theming or the thrills.

All that being said, I don't think the Monte Carlo is a bad place for those looking for budget accommodations. I just know I won't be going back because there are much better places to stay for the same price range.

A positive is that it looks like they have a wonderful pool area including wave pool and lazy river. Due to time's sake, we did not get to experience these but if you have kids in Vegas, looks like a cool place for them.

Couple years ago I stayed here and had an issue and the staff fixed it and made my stay perfect since then I have stayed here almost everytime I am here in Vegas. The service and rooms are wonderful. 
The food court is right next to the hotel elevators and the main table pit is close. The beverage staff are so quick and sweet.
This is becoming one of my favorite hotels because of the customer service.

Monte Carlo Hotel and Resort = Monaco Themed 
Opened June 21, 1996

Recently, I received an offer online from my Mlife for, Buy One Night - Get One Free, I couldn't turn it down because of the free night, plus they had the lazy river ride. =D

Being one of the older hotels on the strip, I didn't expect much based on the Yelp reviews and not being update and have ethernet wasn't really an issue for me. 

Cleanliness and customer service are big factors for me!

As usual, when driving from Southern California, I always use the self parking garage because valet is just a waste of time! Just dropping off your car and picking it up is just  unnecessary for me. Checking in, the front desk clerk was friendly and tried to do the usual as any other agent and upgrade me to a more expensive room but I declined. My deluxe room needed to be renovated to 2013's standards but it was very clean. The bathroom was outdated as well the water pressure from the shower was weak!   

They offer budget friendly eats like a food court to the more expensive restaurants like Brand. A few shops here and there for the typical Vegas tourists and the drink waitresses weren't around as much, maybe I picked a bad location in the casino to gamble. =\/  

This isn't the Bellagio, Aria, or Caesar's Palace, but it did get the job done. I hope the renovations modernize the hotel rooms as well as the 90's style casino. I would give Monte Carlo another try after the renovations. For now, it's 3 stars for me.
Rooms were very old they need to update it the casino and hotel itself was not bad.

We stayed in a spa suite on the 31st floor 9\/5 to 9\/8\/16. The room was clean and the jacuzzi spa tub was a big bonus. We enjoyed most of the amenities and we had a good time and met some nice people at the pool area. We are a couple in our middle years and we had an amazing time and I can't wait to see the remodel. All of the staff we encountered were very friendly and exhibited excellent customer service skills. They made it a very pleasant trip for my husband and I. Great anniversary trip! Thanks and cheers to the staff; good job!

POOL area is only for hooking up. 

The hotel was very nice. The room was great. The staff was very friendly. The reason we booked here was for the pool. I do not recommend it if you are expecting to enjoy the pool area. It is not very family friendly and the lazy river was a standing room only for singles. Parts of the river you couldn't even get through. Also the staff has an attitude that anything goes until someone gets hurt. There was several footballs being thrown around, not a place for this. Security and management finally did something after I got hit with one and let them know. Too many young people trying hook up and don't care about everyone else there trying to have an enjoyable time. The buffet is very nice and a lot of great food.

Just stayed here four days with the fam...average place. Rooms were outdated, stuck in 90s decor and in need of updating. You get what you pay for. Pools were a plus. Lazy river and wave pool were great for kids. Overall, pool area is great and suited for kids and fam.

I guess we can start off by saying how extremely disappointed I was at this resort.  The room was smaller than expected,  but that wasn't the problem. The hotel desk was friendly enough, I suppose but that wasn't the problem either.  When I first checked in i realized i was on one if the lower floors, not a big deal but I wanted something with a view. Spoke to the front desk whocouldnt upgrade me even though they had coming available.  So they put me on some sort of waiting list, quoted me a price and said come back in an hour. I did so. Only to learn that all the "coming available" rooms were now booked.  Not a phone call. Nothing. So I decided to move to a higher floor. Still charged me an upgrade free for the exact same room just higher in the building. Not a big deal.  Friend of mine joined me, and we went out.  Next day wake up in my bed and I find that I had been sleeping on sheets stained with what appeared to be blood.  My fault for not saying anything.  Later on, come back to find that house cleaning changed the sheets.  I was going to leave it alone.  A week later I get a survey. Fill it out. And a few days later, they actually contact me.  Not once have I been able to get a hold of the guy who's signature was in the email. He's never there.  Doesn't respond to emails eithet. So the token effort pretending to care only irritated me.  Call the front desk and I'm informed that I should never have been charged an upgrade fee to change floors and they're going to refund the resort fees for that one night.  And i was promised that someone would contact me to discuss my stay.  Almost a full month later. Still waiting.  Spend your hard earned money elsewhere.

Stayed here during my most recent visit. I've stayed at many properties in Vegas, and this one is above average. Probably not worth much over $100 per night, as there are too many other options above that mark. The main entrance is a bit goofy, as it's on the side. When you stay in Vegas at a resort casino, you'd probably like to drive up at a grand entrance and know what the place looks like from the outside. Instead, you go around to the side to a dreary entrance. 

The staff was courteous and accommodating, so no complaints there.  We took in the Frank Caliendo show which was pretty entertaining, despite some of the reviews on it. I'd stay here again, but only at the right price.

Honestly, for the price and the location, Monte Carlo is worth a stay. I'd do it again. 

Pros:
- Location: can walk along strip; about a 10 minute walk to Caesar's Palace\/Harrah's and Casino Royale; the hotel\/casino is connected to Aria, which is gorgeous
- Transportation: there's a free tram to Aria and Bellagio
- Food court: has Starbucks (!!) and cheap options like Subway, Sbarro's, McDonald's, etc
- Internet (ethernet cord), k-cups, and waters included in hotel fee (also gym and pool)
- Can control the in-room climate
- Fun pool scene, chairs are always available (even in pairs)
- Had standard room amenities like blow dryer, iron, shampoos\/soaps\/lotions
- Mostly clean (we passed by rooms being cleaned for turnover and housekeepers had furniture moved around so they could clean and vacuum every nook and cranny)
- Modern gym with all the fixins -- plus, you get to walk through the spa, which helps gets you into relaxation mode
- Shopping mall with cupcake store, froyo buffet, inexpensive women's clothing
- In-house restaurants were just OK, but D'vino was particularly good -- they have bar food specials, $6 apps with a drink, and the plates were huge and delicious
- CVS is a 2-minute walk, right beside the casino entrance -- SO useful


Cons:
- Awful casino... high limits, no cocktail waitresses to be seen ANYwhere, many games have moved over to electronic. Just not a fun atmosphere. Go gamble somewhere else, like MGM or Casino Royale. 
- $20+\/night resort fee is pretty high... although, most hotels on the strip charge a fee, and at least this one included some useful stuff
- No nice clubs in-house... although it was easy enough to walk to Hakkasan in MGM or Aria's Haze (in heels!)
- Found multiple holes in our room's walls and sheets... when we complained, they changed our sheets, but we found burn-holes in the new ones. Yeesh. Front desk was nice about it though and gave us a $50 voucher for in-house food credits
- They really, really need to upgrade to WiFi internet 
- There was construction outside the front facade our whole stay, which was pretty gross-looking and noisy but hey, I understand if they gotta renovate


All in all, a worthwhile visit, although the hotel isn't super luxurious, and could honestly use some renovation inside. But I would be into staying at the Monte Carlo again, given all the pros.

This place is nothing special!! 

1st.   There was no microwave or fridge in the room.
2nd.  The wi-fi signal was so weak, it was not worth using!!
3rd.   You get a shot of coffee but no cream or sugar with it and by the time you get    
some, your coffee is cold!!  
4th. do not plan on eating there!! The food sucks!!

Pros: Walking distance to T-Mobile Center, Pool Side Service was absolutely great; Rue took care of our group on Saturday and Tiffany in our cabana on Sunday.  

Cons: Room 16-001... Dirty Room, Out Dated, Torn Towels, Dusty, Plumbing Issues, stains on ALL the furniture and carpet... I did tell house keeping but nothing was ever done during our stay.  See photos.  

I get that they are doing a huge remodel\/rebrand, "The Park"... Because the staff tell you all the time. We heard all about it when we checked in, at the pool, from the room service gal, and the valet; it's like they know their hotel is in poor standard and they are using the up coming rebrand as an excuse; Never okay to slack on cleanliness!!!  Never!  

Oh one more con... this is a Pepsi Products resort... If your a Diet Coke person like me you won't find any here!

We have stayed here many times and have enjoyed the hotel and casino areas.  This time however, was not the case.  We were woken up at 6:15 am to drilling and hammering.  I'm not sure why contractors are allowed to disturb guests so early, but we won't be back.  They don't tell you prior to check in so we just wanted to warn others looking for a nice night to look elsewhere.  Unacceptable!

Had a great experience at the Monte Carlo this past week. My bf and I stayed two nights from Wednesday to Friday. Check in wasn't bad at all. Our front desk clerk, Crystal, was super friendly and even helped us out by getting the incidental fee reduced since we had a misunderstanding of how was going to be charged.

We had a spa suite. We loved the room. Our view was of the on-going construction for the new theatre they're building, so that was a bit of a downer but we still had a slight view of the strip. Bed were super comfy, pillows were a little too fluffy for me but my bf loved them. The bathroom was huge and clean. The wet bar was nice. The furniture was a little dated, but not too bad to complain about. 

This casino was pretty much in the middle of everything and connected the the Aria. The CVS right next door was pretty convenient and we loved the food court with all the quick and similar fast food places. 

For the price you pay, you get a good room with really good customer service from the valet to the checkout. Definitely will stay again.

Hello everyone!
Here in Vegas with my fiancee and my brother and sister in law on memorial day weekend. Yes the city is packed full of people... the hotel was busy on Saturday afternoon but we luckily got to check in at the vip room which was pretty fast. Now what makes this hotel great is not it's rooms but in the fact that it's connected to a Tram that connects the Monte Carlo to the Aria Crystals to Bellagio!!! That is huge for people who want to travel several hotels worth in minutes and disembark at bellagio which is in the middle of the strip! And it's free!! 
My most recent experience is probably the lowest of all of them but for some reason when my fiancee and I walked into our room it had a trace smell of something resembling pot... not very pleasant. But the other times we have been here rooms have been fine and clean. 

Have fun everyone and good luck to our fellow gamblers!!!

This hotel is overpriced and not really worth it !! In general all hotels on the strip are a bit overpriced but the room felt cheap and we paid extra for a nicer room with a view (deluxe). There is nothing "deluxe" about it. It felt old, like a motel 6. The furniture is not nice there isn't a fridge the tv is 20" The view wasn't all that either. We also asked for King and got 2 queen bedroom. From the aesthetic from the check in and lobby area and walkways you'd expect something a bit nicer. A similar feel in the room and we were definitely disappointed. 
The only plus to this hotel is the pool area it was LIT, good music good food and good drinks the bar tenders are really good. That is the only reason I give it 2 stars. 
If you are staying for 2 or 3 days or a weekend definitely pay the $20 more for any other hotel bc this one is not worth it. The buffet might trick you into being an incentive but it was horrible. No type of service and the food is not all that great. Felt like a cheaper version of hometown buffet. And that is the general service you receive if you call customer service. We asked for a in room menu we got it a day later. The phone lines are always busy also. 
This hotel was just a horrible experience, not worth the money they charge. I wouldn't have minded if it was $69\/night bc that's what you get. Not even. Motel 6 is better. Stay somewhere else.

Stayed at the Monte Carlo on my most recent trip out for a conference. After having stayed at the Aria on each of my last three trips, I can't say that I was surprised by the "letdown." Apples and oranges. That said, the hotel is actually pretty decent and worth a look if you can catch a good deal on the rate.

I booked a Diamond Suite (caught a very good rate) and after reading some of the other reviews (post-stay), I'm glad I did. It was plenty spacious and was very quite. The room decor and wall coverings are a bit outdated, but the hotel is one of the older on the Strip (built in '96, I believe), so I can't say that I wasn't surprised. But you'd think they'd pay attention to updating the rooms as much as they do the casino floor. But anyway ...

There were other little annoyances that could potentially turn into nightmares for some folks. Like the Wi-Fi. It sucks. No better way of putting it. It is actually free, even on the higher floors (despite what the signs in the lobby say) but it's so weak you might as well not even bother. The engineering guy, Jack, was super helpful (big props to the staff which I found to be very helpful and very courteous), but even he couldn't help with the weak signal. I didn't really need internet access much (thankfully), but if you need to do any business, you may be out of luck. And speaking of business, don't bother with doing anything down in the business center. Just don't. Most business center kiosk software sucks and the software running on their 4 machines is lousy.

Back to the room. As I said, the suite was spacious and very clean. It had an EMPTY  fridge, which is a HUGE plus (don't event think about putting anything of your own into the mini-bar in Aria). Bathrooms were adequate, but being 6'7" with shower-heads placed for people 5'7" was a bit of a let down. I'm not much of a tub guy but the tub was the size of a small pool. It's huge. If that's your thing, you'll enjoy that.

The room's view of the mountains was great and I watched quite a bit of the construction of the new arena being built across the street. Once that thing is completed, the view is going to be 100x better.

The food selection was great and the quality was actually better than most of the other hotels. The casino is, well, a casino - once you've seen one, you've seen them all, really. Not quite as smokey as some of the others, but well laid out and not as cavernous as most. Tons of table games (which I liked). Proximity to Aria and Bellagio via the tram was cool and made for easy access to most everywhere if you want to walk.

Overall, once I brought my expectations back down to earth (Aria kind of spoils you), I enjoyed the hotel. I'm going to spread my wings a bit and try another location on my next trip, like The Venetian or the Wynn, but I would not rule out another stay here.

I went to Las Vegas with three girlfriends in July 2013 and we wanted somewhere with a great location that was cheap.  I read a ton of yelp reviews and decided to take a chance on the Monte Carlo.  And overall, I was glad that I did.  

We checked in two hours prior to the "official" check-in time and the staff was very accommodating, even upgrading us to an upper-floor, strip view.  We went up to the room and were initially quite pleased.  But if yelp has taught me anything, it's to check the bedspreads.  And sure enough, one of them had a nasty stain. Yuck!   I pulled back the covers and found a hair.  Yep.  So it had to go.  I tore the bedding off the bed and called housekeeping to bring us new bedding and some extra towels.  We went down to the pool for a couple of hours and when we came back the beds had been remade and everything was clean.  The desk chair had a stain and the furniture was pretty outdated, but overall we were pretty satisfied with our room. We did choose to stay here because it was cheap after all...  

The location didn't disappoint.  The Monte Carlo is a short walk from the Strip, which makes it easy to walk to a lot of other casinos and restaurants.  We didn't spend that much time at the MC, opting to walk through the other casinos and hang out in the nightclubs at the Paris and the Wynn.  There is a decent food court near the pool entrance at the Monte Carlo which was convenient for breakfast and lunch when we didn't want anything that would take long or cost a lot. 

Part of why we chose the Monte Carlo was the pool, which we all enjoyed. The poolside food and beverage service was a total disappointment though (we couldn't get a server since we weren't in a cabana!) but we were able to snag some free chairs and circle the lazy river on inner tubes.  The pool clientele was pretty laid back and there weren't that many kids around (which we appreciated).  The Monte Carlo pools have their own yelp reviews that I would encourage you to check out if pools are important to you.  

Overall I would definitely recommend this casino to the budget traveler.  It's affordable, relatively clean (once you call housekeeping!), and well located.

Stayed here Feb 17, 2016 to attend the George Strait concert at the new T Mobile Area which is right across the street. The room was called the run of the house booked through Hotels.com. It was 2 queens which is fine. The cost was $135.00 plus $36.00 for resort fee plus $13.00 a day parking. 
The room looks like about a $50 room. Old out dated furniture scratched up. Old mattresses,  one chair with worn aphostery and strings hanging off the front and a hole.
No alarm clock or anything else. The bare essentials. Not much better than a motel 8. Will NEVER stay here again. They should be ashamed to charge this much for a room looking like this.

Beautiful Casino. The Scent this Casino has is among the best in Vegas. Slots were also not too tight, alot of casinoes on strip make their slot odds too tight, but Monte Carlo doesn't as much and I like that. However their are casinoes where the odds are better like Arizona Charlies located in East Las Vegas off the strip.

Average rooms good price and great location on the strip. 
Resort fees is a minus but in all good stay!

The place is super old and nasty. The bed was dirty and greasy. I called the front desk about this being a deluxe room but they said that's what you paid extra for. I asked what did I pay extra for with no coffee maker no fridge a dingy carpet and a patched up wall!

This review is for the mlife desk at Monte Carlo.  While my girl was being helped by a gentleman the lady mlife rep next to him made a racist comment saying "this is not Japan we don't work fast".  When my girl told her we were from Korea, she then starting making comments about Korea.  When I confronted her she acted like it was not a big deal.   I then spoke with her supervisor and she apologized for her action but it still pissed me off.  I've stayed in this hotel 3-4 times in the last year or so but this event pissed me off so much I may have to change to a different hotel on our next trip.

This is not my first time in Vegas and nor is it my first time at an MGM property. I'm so disappointed by this. I checked in here last night and have another 4 days ahead of me and I already regret the decision of staying here at the Monte Carlo so much that it's 6am and I'm writing this review.

I paid $155 per night at the time of booking and then turns out theres an additional $50 per night deposit and a $33.60 per accommodation per night resort fee. What does that even mean? Why not just include all charges up front in the advertised prices instead of misleading customers. Effectively I've paid more than $200 per night which is ridiculous for this place.

The rooms are ancient. I really mean ANCIENT. They are bare bones with no amenities at all. The lamps, tables, chairs and all fittings are busted up, scratched all over the place and stained and the dusty stained carpets in the rooms and the hallways make you feel like you're in some cheap motel. Not enough sockets to charge devices and the walls are so thin that you can hear all the bathrooms around. I was woken up at 5am today by a kid crying in the adjacent room.

The bathrooms are tiny and have really old fittings. The shower is cracked and dirty all over, the wash basin tap makes a sound like the whistle of a pressure cooker going off and the taps require a fair bit of force to turn and have no precision to getting that perfect lukewarm water is a challenge.

The only thing I've liked about my experience so far was the guy at the front desk who checked me in. He was extremely nice and friendly. 

I looked at some of the other reviews and I see the Guest Relations Manager comment on them about the "extensive renovation process" that's underway. The thing is, this apology\/explanation really doesn't fix anything and makes people's stay unpleasant, especially for those who are actually planning to use their rooms a fair bit. They really should make these thing clear at the time of booking so that people know what they are paying for. 

I'm extremely disappointed and embarrassed since I recommended and booked rooms for some more colleagues from my company. We are here in Vegas pretty often for conferences and are trying to scope our goto hotel so that we can just do recurring bookings with them. I was hoping that the Monte Carlo would be the one due to it's central location but it doesn't look like that anymore. I'm actually tempted to cancel the rest of our stay and check out and move somewhere else.

The lobby is beautiful! We Checked in rather late and they were very accommodating. Everything was already paid in full. There is a resort fee for $34ish a day plus we parked our rental in the garage for $8 a day. The room was a little out dated but clean which is all that matters. The shower is spacious but the actual shower and tub could be more spacious. Not bad though. The pool area is amazing. Very big, loud music lots of bars.

My husband and I come to Las Vegas at least once a year. We have stayed in 6 or 7 hotels on the strip. This trip we decided to stay at the Monte Carlo, which was a big mistake. We checked in and went to our room,  it was terrible. All the furniture was beat up and dirty, the chair looked as if it had been picked out of a garbage dump. Truly. We didn't have enough pillows,  no face cloths, no ironing board, the remote control didn't work, there was a hole in the desk top, and the a.c. didn't work right. We went to talk to a manager, and she told us that all the rooms would be the same, due to the age of the furniture. Aside from the shape of the rooms, the customer service was really awful too.

This hotel stay was great. We had been here on our first trip to Vegas way back in 2007. The hotel does show some age but the service was impeccable! Whether it was checking in, checking out, exiting the garage or eating at the buffet...the service was always with a smile.  

Our rooms were clean and the maid was very nice. We also had great luck with the casino. It was not too big and not too small. Just right! Sadly this hotel is being renovated and will no longer be the Monte Carlo. The Monte Carlo took care of us very well and I can't wait to come back.

Our family stayed here for 2 nights on our recent vacation.  Our rooms were just OK - they need updating and they weren't spotless - I don't think our rooms were vacuumed prior to us staying there.  I was impressed by the spa and exercise room.  This is certainly not the most glamorous hotel on the strip, but the price was right for us as it was only a stopover on our way to the Grand Canyon.  This hotel was conveniently located near some of the bigger hotels.  I was a little surprised that you had to rent a tube to ride on the lazy river - it would be nice if that was included in the use of the pool area - I thought the resort fee per person would cover little things like that.

Stayed at the Monte Carlo for my birthday weekend for 3 nights.  the room rates were reasonable, esp for a weekend, but it was a random weekend.  I got a coupon book which was pretty neat, my cousin and i def took advantage of that!  Rooms were clean and comfy.  The tv's weren't so nice, but it's Vegas, i guess they don't want you to stay in the room anyways hehe!

Alright...bullet points on this one:

1.  Nice looking hotel at very nice prices
2.  Standard rooms comes with a TV from about 1992 and it is 13 inches or so?  That's okay...you should not be in your room watching TV.  You should be in there to nurse a hangover. 
3.  Slow drain in the sinks in some of the rooms, but not in ours.
4.  $10 Pai Gow tables make me supremely happy
5.  Nice and efficient cocktail waitresses on the casino floor
6.  What???  Sam Adams is the darkest beer you have?  No Newcastle?  No Guinness? BAH!
7.  The buffet food for weddings (should you decide to have a wedding here or you are a guest at one) is A-MAY-ZING!  Seriously good, quality food and a whole table of desserts in addition to the cake.
8.  The Frank Caliendo Show advertisements on repeat in every elevator was god damn annoying.  I wanted to punch those little TV screens after a few trips.
9.  Don't ever order at a bar in the Casino, unless you are playing video poker - it cost us $16 for a bottle of Sam Adams and a Jack & Coke.  I am too cheap for that nonsense and I should've known better.
10.  Excellent location on The Strip!

All in all, this is now on my list of hotels I would stay at again and will keep in the rotation on where to stay in Vegas.

Not one of my faves but we decided to drop by here before our dinner date at Smith and Wollenskys which is right across the street. 

We decided to play some slots after dinner and cocktail service was pretty nonexistent. We were there a good 2.5 hours and I only saw the cocktail waitress a few times. 

My next complaint is how smoky the place is. Cigarette smoke gives me a headache and yes, I know it's everywhere in Vegas but I felt like the stench was so much stronger in Monte Carlo. They need a better air filtration system. My clothes absolutely reeked of cigarette smoke when I walked out of there. I'll save my lungs and go elsewhere next time.

I would have left 0 stars but I couldn't. 
My Brother who is disabled was not accommodated and was lied to about our room. Accommodating all of us even though they said they would. They made us feel like it was our fault, and wouldn't help us out 
I'm didn't spend all that money to sleep almost on the floor. Never staying here again or MGM Resorts

You get what you pay for!
Adequate 2-star quality rooms, with poor lighting.  No quick check-in or check-out process. If you have non-carry-on luggage, it gets hauled away and you will wait at least 1\/2 hour before you have it brought to you room.  The internet didnt work and we had to wait over an hour for a tech to fix the problem.  The fitness center requires paperwork every time, including upon exiting, a wasted 3 minutes. Some machines didnt work. Pool area crowded. No HBO - even Motel 6 has it! No mini-fridge, no microwave, no coffeemaker. Hairdryer and iron with ironing board, yes.  Shampoo, conditioner and lotion, yes.  One plus: clean rooms and a friendly, prompt and efficient housekeeping staff.  Not-so-friendly lobby staff. Valet parking, so take all you need to you room. "Resort" fee (ha ha): $12.95 plus tax added to your rate (8 oz. bottle  of generic H2O, internet access, fitness center with shower NOT included - $5 fee with sauna and hot tub addtional).
A one-time deal for my wife and I.  We wont be back...

Last minute room needed had high hopes quickly got over that. Hotel is under major construction, no pool, have to either walk or take a tram to neighboring hotels. Got in my bath tub to soak for a min after a long drive and saw mold and hair and just filth under the soap dish. Just gross! Not that hard to spray some bleach in a tub while cleaning. Also I'm paying a resort fee for what??? No pool, no fridge in the rooms, no coffee maker, no plastic cups even!!! So what the hell are they charging a resort fee for??? Oh and $15 a day to valet my car??? I'm a hotel guest!!!
Safe to say that the check in desk is grossly understaffed for a Friday night. Why do people not know how to manage staffing needs?

We came to the Monte Carlo hoping to get a deal on a room + the Jabbawockeez show. As it turned out, the rooms were cheap. 

We walked into the hotel the night we wanted to stay there and ended up with a Monaco Suite for about $70. This room was about 700 ft. and had one and a half bath. The room layout was a little odd so it felt as though the space wasn't being used the most effectively. The room came with a flat screen TV but was placed a good 15+ feet away from the bed so it looked really small. Our view was rather horrendous being mostly the roof of the casino and just a little bit of the strip. As far as other Yelper's comments about traveling sound, we didn't once hear a neighbor or someone walking in the halls (and we were right next to the elevator). The other reviews are accurate regarding the rooms being, ah, aromatic. The wired internet would not work at all but the wifi was solid. The room seemed clean enough. It was simply a one night stay and it isn't really like I plan to spend all that much time in my room anyway. There are much better things to do in Vegas.

We didn't check out the spa. Which I rather wished we had since the fee it automatically added. We were actually looking to get the spa suite but they were all booked for the night.

The Jabbawockeez show (MUS I C) was a lot of fun. We got a 15% discount since we stayed in the hotel. It wasn't a great deal but I appreciate any discount willingly given.

The casino floor seemed to me to be on the small side. There were a decent amount of slot machines but not a ton of tables. We were hoping that maybe they had two sets of tables, but after walking from one end of the casino to the other, we realized we would have to make due with what we saw. All of the staff was friendly. The players card works for all MGM casinos so I was able to still use the one from when I stayed at the Mirage. 

I did win $500 at one of the Wheel of Fortune machines. Does this have anything to do with the Monte Carlo Casino itself? No. BUT I GOT TO WIN $500! That is bound to color any trip just a little bit better! =)

Basically stayed here because of location on the strip and price. Gotta say this is probably the worst hotel I have stayed at on the strip the only thing I can say about this place that is positive is the location. Its located better on the than Luxor and they where about the same price. 

The Monte Carlo is atleast going through a massive remodel so things will be looking up for the property and I'm sure prices will be a lot better bet gotta say MGM should be embarrassed of this property right now because I had a stained sheet on my bed. Also the carpet in the room was shaggy several places in the room had wallpaper peeling off the wall. Also the a\/c didn't work that well.

Most of the places in hotel seemed to close a little early in the evening which kind of sucked because I wanted to grab something b4 I went up and it was only 11pm but whatever. 

I won't be staying here again maybe after the remodel but for right now it would be hard for me to stay here for free. This property should be embarrassed to charge a resort fee with the rooms looking that they have been furnished in Salvation Army decor!
@MonteCarloVegas after driving 10 hours from SFO to see Cher - show-cancelled,  hotel offers NOTHING, NO COMP just a "free" cancellation SAD

I had never stayed here before and I must say for the money it's a great deal.  We went for a weekend in March and had a great stay.  The entry of the hotel is very nice, the individual oil lamp look-a-likes at each guest check in desk were a nice touch.  Personally I liked on each level how there's a center lobby right off the elevator with 4 different hallways to go down for your room.. it's nothing spectacular but for some reason I really liked it.

The room's are pretty nice, definitely nicer than a lot of the hotels in a similar price range... I'm thinking that we got a good price because we went 2 months after the fire that occurred there... no concern to me.

Everytime I venture to Vegas I never really get to enjoy the pools and other commodities at the hotel, of course this trip was no different though I'm sure they were great.

The service at the hotel was exquisite, I definitely recommend it..

Pros and Cons  mixed - Contradictions at its finest :) 

Check-in process was one of the longest, if not the longest, of my life...and there was only one person in front of us, and we were in the 'invited' line.   While the lady was pleasant and whacky enough for my liking, my husband put it best, "It seems like she just came here today for the first time and pretended to work here."

Nice 40 inch t.v. at least in the 29th floor rooms - from these reviews on here, it seems that the higher floors are considered slight upgrades...we were with a Gold Member, so unsure if this is why our rooms were upgraded\/if it was considered an upgrade..we were on the same floor.

Pool Area is pretty good, but it opens not until 9 a.m.  For the summer months especially, when it's already 90-95 degrees by 9 a.m., it would be much better to have the pool open earlier...and close later.

Dealers, some were duds, some were decent.

Extremely rude player's club staff lady.  Gave attitude for my husband getting a player's card because he had left his home (in Chicago), which I have to imagine many, if not most people do.  With that being said....she said, "Let's make sure we don't have to do this again" - later on, he realized after all that, his name was spelled wrong, an extra two letters added on.  

Spacious rooms and very clean, I would eat off the floor.  However, the amount of space goes to waste with no refrigerator\/microwave\/couch\/sofabed, etc.  Shampoo\/Conditioner and like amenities are decent.

Housekeeping did not come to service our room the second day we were there.  We did have our "Do Not Disturb" sign on until approximately 10 a.m., and then it was off for the rest of the day.  No service.  We could have benefited from an extra towel or two, but it wasn't that big of a deal.    

Internet, while included in the $20\/day resort fee (additional cost to your rooms), is average, at best.  

Spa area at $10 a day (additional to the resort fee) is actually quite good.  While initially it is irritating, that using the spa facilities (whirlpool, sauna, and steam room), is not included in the resort fee, it is worth it.  I will probably do a separate review for the spa, as I give it 4 stars.  Massages\/facials and what not are your standard over-the-top prices but still probably not as much as other MGM properties.  

Free tram connected to Monte Carlo does take you to the Bellagio, and it's usually only a couple minutes or so wait.  

Room service?  Forget about it.  Tried to call two different times, waiting first for 10 minutes, then at another time for 15 minutes, on hold.  

Starbucks staff (a guy) sucked, as he took orders from an obvious friend of his, and then continued to talk to his friend instead of taking next in line customers.  Finally, when we were "assisted," he was stand-offish.  When asked to toast the bagels, he said, "Oh no, we don't do that.  The other Starbucks [food court] does that though."  

Would stay here again if rooms were about 10 bucks cheaper than what we paid, on average of $55\/night.  Probably will not stay again, however.

Biggest disappointment!! The worst hotel I have ever stayed in for the price I have paid. You will literally feel cheated. The hotel is so dated. There's construction next door. I got keys to my room to find at least 8 moths flying around, dirty towel on the floor, dirty toilet with seat open, used ice, used plastic bag on the table. It was sheer disappointment as a start to Vegas trip. When I went back to the reception and complained, they didn't look too surprised and said the hotel has no plans for renovation till later next year and then it would take another year. Then I got a different room which wasn't much change. The lamp shades were torn and broken, the sheets grey and faded, the bathroom like a cheap motel, the mattress uncomfortable and the pillows flattened! When I said I want to cancel my reservation, they said I still have to pay $40 for each day of the reservation as a resort fee! I haven't even stayed there for 10 mins! BTW: this is a hidden charge that you have to pay in addition to the hotel fee.

I would not recommend this hotel to anyone and I will never ever return here either!

I stayed at the Monte Carlo during EDC weekend 2013 for 5 nights. I've come to Vegas many times and have always encountered a problem at some point during my stay. The Monte Carlo did NOT follow the trend. We arrived at the resort around 9:30am, however check-in isn't til' 3pm. Not a problem, the front desk employee not only allowed us to check-in early but she gave a us a good room overlooking the pool. The lazy river and the wave pool were really enjoyable especially with a DJ spinnin' house music as you swim and drink. The casino, pool, front lobby, parking lot and dinning areas are all relatively close to each other which is great if you dont like having to walk a mile to get from one place to another. 4 stars instead of 5 because our bathtub and sink kept clogging even after we asked someone to service it. The innertubes should be free if you're a guest at the hotel. $5 a tube isn't really worth it. Beds were comfortable and the rooms were tidy. Everything was clean for the most part. EDC is a busy time but Monte Carlo made it comfortable and relaxing.

The Monte Carlo is a decent hotel on the strip.  The rooms need upgrading and the pool is overrated. The wave pool is much smaller than the pictures suggest and the lazy river is always really busy.  The pool also closes at 7pm.  The good news is that they are undertaking major renovations and will be closing next summer for upgrades. They are also building additions to the property.  

The lobby areas, spa, fitness center, and shops are pretty good and the staff were all great.

I do not recommend this hotel at all! The rooms are dirty no joke!! Dirty floors , nasty uncomfortable bed! The restroom is disgusting the bath tub creepy old with mold! No wifi! No fridge!! If you want a fridge That's an extra $25 a day never heard of that before! The safe didn't work! The sheets had blood and they didn't want to give my boyfriend a refund we had to pay cancelation fees! It was just horrible!! Never again!!
The room was very nice.  We were really able to relax after a 9 hr drive. All the staff we encountered were very friendly and made our stay enjoyable.

DO NOT STAY HERE. The construction that is going on surrounding the hotel is awful. If you are looking for a peaceful nights sleep after hanging out you will not get it here.  The pool area has been run over by the construction site and feels like it is getting swallowed up, it is not very clean-trash floating in the wave pool. When I called to ask about the construction going on around the hotel they acted like it was not a big deal and the noise was not an issue. IT is a BIG DEAL, they are putting up at least 6 new buildings. Not to mention the work that they have going on at the hotel. They work at night on these buildings please don't let them lie to you.  Our room was run down and dirty.  The furniture was falling apart.  We tried to change rooms and they told us they were booked.  Not worth the money.

I stayed two nights at the Monte Carlo Casino and Resort. The casino itself is classy and has a great variety of restaurants. It looks like they're adding on a concert hall of some kind which will be awesome. It's right next to T-Mobile Arena which is why we chose to stay there. The pool is awesome and then cabana service was superb. Only thing I would recommend for the resort to do in the future is start updating the rooms. The rooms look very old and o hate the fact we had to ask for a mini fridge and microwave, which should normally come with a room already. I also hate the fact that MGM changes for parking now. But overall a good experience. Front desk service was excellent and friendly. Bellhop service was very fast and helpful.

I have stayed there twice.  The second time I stayed and found out that the night life or lounge they called Brand Steakhouse and Lounge is a very tiny lounge which is converted from a regular steakhouse restaurant during day time to night time as Lounge.  The admission fee is $30.  I totally do not recommend to go in.  Don't go in unless it is free.  The DJ isn't that great either.

Just got back and gotta say that the MC didn't meet my expectations. I usually stay at NYNY but got so tired of their poor pool area that I tried the MC, which looked to have about 4 pools, including a wave pool.

Well here's the bad-
The entire MC parking structure is closed to guests! They use it for the City Center construction workers! I was like, WTF? Shouldn't they make those guys car pool or take the freakin' BUS and maybe we'd have less congestion on the Strip? 
So I managed to somehow find a space in the adjacent lot and wheel my suitcase 1\/8 of a mile to the lobby.
The check-in area doesn't have a single line for everyone, but you just pick one host and stand in their line, and watch as others come up and get rooms while you wait behind the slow lady!
The pool area was great, with lots of sun, but they were playing music way too freakin' loud. I won't be back because of that, as I don't think it will change. I couldn't hear the waitress, when she finally managed to drag her tanned ass away from the bartender to ask me what I wanted!
The rooms are way too ordinary for the prices you pay on the weekends.
The buffet was nothing special with a small selection.

The good news is that most of the service there is very good, the location is nice, Diablo's is a rockin' good bar right on the Strip and Andre's really lived up to it high ratings. The food there was the best, plus the concierge had given us a coupon for $25 off when we asked how to get to the restaurant.  The only bummer was that they wouldn't allow me to open my own bottle of wine, which I had brought to celebrate my birthday. This was a rare vintage which they didn't have and I was willing to spend the same corkage as I paid at Mon Ami Gabi ($25) but they have a strict no outside wine policy.

So while I was expecting a little more upscale adult hotel\/ casino I found it to be catering to the younger crowd, much like all the other MGM properties in the area. Next time I will have to try Caesars.

Let's see, where do I start?  They charged a "resort fee" at the front desk and for every single one of the people I was with, didn't mention what the resort fee is for: wired (no wireless, available) internet and two bottles of water in your room.  Well, to get my internet to work, I had to call the front desk three times - the first two times they hung up on me while I was waiting on hold... for over 5-minutes!  And they told me I they don't deliver water bottles anymore.  That would be fine if they admitted what the resort fee was for and gave me something to compensate without me having to demand something.  Mind you, water bottles in a room cost $10.  So I got them to give me two $10 drink coupons.  Only thing is, thouse coupons are only valid in casino bars and, as we all know, drinks are already free in casino bars... so basically I paid a resort fee for antiquated internet (wired) and no bottles of water.  Ridiculous...

On to the staff.  Check-in took forever because there was no management of the hoard of people waiting to check-in.  I waited in one spot, and others who arrived after me cut in front of me.  The front desk people didn't care and instead spent their time trying to upsell people to a bigger room.  Check people in!!  Get it done!!

The casino sucks here.  It's mostly slot machines, which is normal, but there are far too few low dollar and mid-dollar blackjack tables.  The dealers are gross people too: almost every one of them was white trash.  I want my dealer to look like he\/she took a shower.

The rooms were average but the sound deadening in-between the door and the hallway and in-between rooms is a joke.  I could hear people having sex, the couple on the other side arguing, and every single door open and close in the the immediate hallway area.  Sleep was hard to come by, even in the nice beds.  I'm baffled why a Las Vegas hotel still has CRT televisions in regular rooms.  Common... it's 2010 - the room shouldn't feel like a Motel 6.  Also, the shower sucked (shower head is too low and immovable) and the light switch and toilet flush handle were impossible to work.  Annoying.

My room was a standard room.  Perhaps there are better rooms here.  Regardless, this isn't a hotel I'd ever return to.  Ever.

We enjoyed our one night stay at this hotel recently.  The rooms were dated, but we paid less than 100 for the night, and got to stay on the strip! We were pleased!  The staff was friendly, the atmosphere was great!  We enjoyed the restaurants and lounges that were in the hotel as well. The only complaint I have is about the wait to check in.  I felt like I was at wal-mart--- you know, all those cash registers, and only 4 people working... This hotel had more than a dozen check in desks, but only 3 or 4 employees working, so we stood in line to check in for about 20 minutes...

Oh, we also saw the Blue Man Group- FANTASTIC show!

Spent 20 minutes waiting for a beer at a table in the first pit closest to the strip at a roulette table.  Eventually walked up to remind the waitress and I heard her cursing out the guy who walked up immediately before me with one of her coworkers.  I immediately said screw this place and left.  Terrible service won't be coming back.  
The waitress was darker skinned with long permed hair about 50 years old.  She needs to go.

No coffee maker, no fridge. Is this standard now?
Resort fees $30-I think Ballys doesn't have resort fees.
I won't stay here again unless the price is comparable when you INCLUDE the high resort fees.

I have so much to say about Monte Carlo after staying there for 5 nights and having visited their pool, lounge, casino, etc. How should I start?

Location:  is great. It's in the middle of the strip. There's a CVS next door and there's an ABC Store, Walgreens, Showcase Mall (M&M World and Coca Cola Store, movie theaters) right across the street. There's also a bus stop where the Deuce and the express stops right in front of Showcase. The only offset about location is that only the Deuce stops in front of Monte Carlo. If you catch the express, you would have to get off either at Bellagio or Excalibur. It's a short walk to both but I think Excalibur is closer. New York New York is right next door as well. There's also a tram that connects you to City Center and Bellagio and you can catch that by going through the shops. 

Rooms:  The rooms are pretty comfy with nice TVs (so not like the old school TVs IP has) with cable. We were able to get adjoining rooms so it felt like we had a suite (if only that wall wasn't in the way) haha. Rooms are not huge but they are decent sized. Walls are a little thin but being Vegas, we never had any complaints. The iHome on our side was broken (it could charge my phone but didn't play music) but the one in our other room worked so we were fine with that. 

Pool: They have a heated pool, lazy river, wave pool, and a huge jacuzzi. You can rent a tube for $10 but we had a special thing so we got 2 for 1 tubes. The wave pool wasn't very strong so I got bored of that pretty quickly. I liked the lazy river but it got so crowded at times :[

Lounge: A friend and I checked out the Brand Lounge on our first night at Monte Carlo. It was $20 for girls and all you can drink. They gave us each a pink cup and we just kept getting refills. It started off super weak at first and got gradually stronger which makes no sense at all. We had a pretty good time there. The crowd is a little older (mid-late 20s).
